text: Introduction
label: Title

text: Rosemarie Haag Bletter
label: Title

text: Adolf Behne’s Der moderne Zweckbau (The Modern Functional Building) pre-
label: Paragraph

text: sciently unmasked many of the ideologies of functionalism, rationalism, and
label: Paragraph

text: European Modernism of the 1920s. Written in 1923 (though not published
label: Paragraph

text: until 1926), it preceded the later German publications of Walter Gropius,
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Hilberseimer, Walter Curt Behrendt, and Bruno Taut and sheds much
label: Paragraph

text: light on them.? Today the Anglo-American audience remains largely familiar
label: Paragraph

text: with European Modernism through the narrow focus of Henry-Russel
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock and Philip Johnson’s The International Style, 1932, although Hitch-
label: Paragraph

text: cock’s earlier Modern Architecture: Romanticism and Reintegration, 1929, had
label: Paragraph

text: presented a somewhat more varied picture of recent developments. By con-
label: Paragraph

text: trast, arguments about Modernism were articulated in surprisingly rich and
label: Paragraph

text: complex ways in the aforementioned European works of the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne's Der moderne Zweckbau is crucial for understanding modernist
label: Paragraph

text: polernics contextually, especially those later subsumed under the notion of
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism. In a general sense, the increasing concern with purpose and
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in early Modernism signifies the change from older, aristo-
label: Paragraph

text: cratic value systems to an emphasis on everyday and common experience
label: Paragraph

text: as the new paradigm. Behne’s text is also helpful in reconsidering some of
label: Paragraph

text: the standard assumptions and questions about this period, especially the
label: Paragraph

text: presumption of a visually coherent style. Instead of emphasizing the exter-
label: Paragraph

text: nal appearance of buildings, German texts dealing with Modernism in the
label: Paragraph

text: 19208 identified the new architecture through its underlying conceptua
label: Paragraph

text: premises. Contemporary expression was therefore seen as a reflection of
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical attitudes toward modernity, and this view allowed for greater
label: Paragraph

text: visual diversity— perhaps only because an exact correspondence between
label: Paragraph

text: idea and form was difficult to establish.
label: Paragraph

text: The three-year delay in the publication of Der moderne Zweckbau reveals
label: Paragraph

text: much about the competitive nature of early Modernism. Gropius had sought
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s assistance in preparing the Bauhaus exhibition Internationale Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tektur in 1923; but when Behne in turn asked Gropius to change the con-
label: Paragraph

text: tent or delay the publication date of the book of the same title (the first entry
label: Paragraph

text: in the Bauhausbiicher, or Bauhaus book series, which was projected for
label: Paragraph

text: publication in 1924) because of its similarity to Behne’s own work, Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: refused. Gropius’s decision to start a book series hampered Behne’s efforts
label: Paragraph

text: on other fronts as well. When Behne shortly thereafter approached J. J. P.
label: Paragraph

text: Oud (whose work Behne had promoted in 1922 in his monograph on Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: architecture) and asked him for material for his own book, Oud responded
label: Paragraph

text: that he would prefer to have his work published in the Bauhaus book series.
label: Paragraph

text: He clearly expected more publicity and credibility given the Bauhaus’s insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tutional backing.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, books such as Gropius's Internationale Architektur, 1925,
label: Paragraph

text: portrayed contemporary architecture —as did Behne —in an astonishingly
label: Paragraph

text: varied way. Frank Lloyd Wright's Larkin Building and Erich Mendeisohn’s
label: Paragraph

text: equally massive-looking double house in Berlin were included among Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: nationale Architektur’s illustrations. Hilberseimer’s Internationale neue Bau-
label: Caption

text: kunst (New international architecture), which appeared in 1927 under the
label: Paragraph

text: auspices of the German Werkbund, was similarly diverse in scope. Its exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ples ranged from an apartment house by Jan Wils to housing by Taut, in
label: Paragraph

text: addition to unexecuted schemes by Russian Constructivists. In Die neue
label: Paragraph

text: Baukunst in Europa und Amerika (simultaneously published in English as
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Architecture), 1929, Bruno Taut was also extraordinarily inclusive in
label: Paragraph

text: his selection of examples.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas several of these books alluded to the perceived internationalism
label: Paragraph

text: of contemporary architecture, only Behrendt’s Der Sieg des newen Baustils
label: Paragraph

text: The victory of the new building style), 1927, treated the new architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: a style, as would Hitchcock and Johnson’s later study.* Notwithstanding his
label: Paragraph

text: title, even Behrendt presented a varied picture of contemporary architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: one that included works by Hans Poelzig, Mendelsohn, and Willem Dudok.
label: Paragraph

text: ie saw Wright's Robie House and Henry van de Velde’s theater at the Werk-
label: Paragraph

text: bund exhibition of 1914 as the key precedents to modern architecture; and
label: Paragraph

text: he presented an organic plan by Hugo Haring next to Ludwig Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe’s De Stijl-inspired plan for a brick country house so that side-by-side
label: Paragraph

text: they appeared as equally central examples of the new style. But because Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: man proselytizers of Modernism tended to downplay the aesthetic aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture, their criteria depended less on visual elements than did
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock and Johnson’s work. Reinforcing this attitudinal difference was
label: Paragraph

text: the fact that contemporary architecture was commonly referred to in Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many as “Neues Bauen” (new building), just as in Holland it was known as
label: Paragraph

text: “Nieuw Bouwen.”5
label: Caption

text: It is not entirely clear why the term Neues Bawen became prevalent in the
label: Paragraph

text: 19208. The word modern was more commonly used prior to 1923, as for
label: Paragraph

text: example in Karl Scheffler’s Moderne Baukunst, 1907, or, for that matter,
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s Der moderne Zweckbau.’ Possibly under the influence of the general
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist conception of the new man, and more specifically the Neues
label: Paragraph

text: Bauen exhibition of 1920 at J. B. Neumann's gallery in Berlin,’ and the popu-
label: Paragraph

text: larization after 1923 of Gustav Hartlaub’s “Neue Sachlichkeit” (conceived by
label: Paragraph

text: him as a further evolution of Expressionism, nota reaction to it), the term new
label: Paragraph

text: attained wide currency among the German avant-garde. Taut’s Die neue Woh-
label: Paragraph

text: nung (The new dwelling), 1924, suggests the link to Expressionism.® Neu
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have implied change and the progressivism associated with the
label: Paragraph

text: new movement more clearly than the term modern. The latter seerns almost
label: Paragraph

text: to have been perceived as a neutral chronological marker synonymous with
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary. Behne himself signifies the shift from modern to neu in his
label: Paragraph

text: Neues Wohnen — Neues Bauen (New dwelling — New building), 1927, and the
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on the new is apparent in the titles of Hilberseimer’s Interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tionale neue Baukunst, Behrendt’s Der Sieg des neuen Baustils, or Taut’s Bauen—
label: Paragraph

text: Der neue Wohnbau (Building — The new domestic architecture), 1927.°
label: Caption

text: It is also possible that neu carried political overtones that had prewar
label: Paragraph

text: origins in Germany. The weekly newspaper of the Social Democrats was
label: Paragraph

text: called Die neve Zeit. Behne wrote an essay for this paper in 1914 on the rep-
label: Paragraph

text: resentation of workers in art. His first book (subsequent to publication of
label: Paragraph

text: his doctoral thesis) was titled Zur neuen Kunst (Toward the new art) and was
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1915 by Der Sturm. Modern in a political context may have
label: Paragraph

text: meant simply “of the present time,” whereas neue Zeit — and by implication
label: Paragraph

text: neu — suggested a rupture with past times.
label: Paragraph

text: Such contextual or regional shifts in terminology do not apply in the
label: Paragraph

text: same way to the Anglo-American sphere, where modern continued to be the
label: Paragraph

text: preferred term. It is significant that Taut’s Die neue Baukunst in Europa und
label: Paragraph

text: Amerika, 1929, appeared in its English edition of the same year under the
label: Paragraph

text: title Modern Architecture. And Behrendt, the author of Der Sieg des neuen
label: Paragraph

text: Baustils, 1927, later, while living in America, wrote Modern Building, 1937.1
label: Caption

text: There are, however, subtle variations even within the more general discus-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of “modern” developments, as Alan Colquhoun has recently pointed
label: Paragraph

text: out.'! Whereas in England in the 1950s the avant-garde of the 1920s was
label: Paragraph

text: generally referred to as the Modern Movement — suggesting a degree of
label: Paragraph

text: activism and ongoing development — today we tend to prefer Modernism, a
label: Paragraph

text: word that seems to denote a historical period.
label: Paragraph

text: To understand the ideology and intricacies of the modernist debate that
label: Paragraph

text: fueled the Neues Bauen, one needs to study more closely the polemics of
label: Paragraph

text: books by the aforementioned German authors. For this purpose Behne’s Der
label: Paragraph

text: moderne Zweckbau is the most revealing text. It fully explores and carefully sets
label: Paragraph

text: the stage for later arguments and for the development of concepts such as
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit (objectivity, functionalism) and Zweck (purpose, function). In this
label: Paragraph

text: respect Behne’s role is comparable to that of Hartlaub in the staging of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of 1925 on the Neue Sachlichkeit in painting.’ Beyond that, Behne,
label: Paragraph

text: a critic of both art and architecture, was also an astute observer of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary scene. Although his writings do not have the acerbic consistency
label: Paragraph

text: of Adolf Loos, many of his essays and books contain sharp, perceptive com-
label: Paragraph

text: ments and critiques of the Werkbund, Expressionism, and the Bauhaus, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the work of close friends. He was not a practicing architect, yet he
label: Paragraph

text: was not exactly a completely detached observer. Bene was a major partici-
label: Paragraph

text: pant in Expressionist architectural groups after World War 1. Like Sigfried
label: Paragraph

text: Giedion, he had the advantage of an academic education in art history and a
label: Paragraph

text: close acquaintance with nearly all of the principal architects of his time.
label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Bruno Behne was born in Magdeburg on 13
label: Paragraph

text: uly 1885, the son of an
label: Paragraph

text: architect. When he was a year old his parents moved with him and his two
label: Paragraph

text: older brothers, Erich and Karl, to Berlin. He grew up
label: Paragraph

text: class districts of eastern Berlin near the Centralvie
label: Paragraph

text: in one of the working-
label: Paragraph

text: hhof (main slaughter-
label: Title

text: house) and attended a Gymnasium from which he graduated in 1905. His
label: Paragraph

text: academic training commenced with the study of architecture at the Techni-
label: Paragraph

text: sche Hochschule (Polytechnic school) in Berlin-Charlottenburg, but in 1907
label: Paragraph

text: he decided to study art history at the Friedrich-Wilhelm Universitat. After a
label: Paragraph

text: stay in Italy, he produced his dissertation, “Der Inkrustationssti] in Toscana”
label: Paragraph

text: (The incrustation style in Tuscany), in 1912. Among his teachers were Hein-
label: Paragraph

text: rich Wolfflin (with whom Giedion had also studied) and Georg Simmel, the
label: Paragraph

text: great philosopher and sociologist. Thereafter he taught in a Hochschule as
label: Paragraph

text: well as a Volkshochschule (an adult education program), and he became part
label: Paragraph

text: of the Volksbildungsbewegung (People’s education movement). This move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment was concerned with furthering education outside of academic institu-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, and it remained an interest for Behne throughout his career. In 1913
label: Paragraph

text: he married Elfriede Schneider, the daughter of a railroad engineer, whom he
label: Paragraph

text: had met through the mathematics club at the university. They had two
label: Paragraph

text: daughters — Karla, born in 1913, and Julia, born in 1921.4
label: Caption

text: Before the war Behne also belonged to the Choriner Kreis (Chorin circle),
label: Paragraph

text: a group of young writers, artists, and architects that met on weekends for
label: Paragraph

text: walks in the woods around the small town of Chorin near Berlin. Max
label: Caption

text: Beckmann and Taut were also members of the group, and Behne formed a
label: Paragraph

text: long-lasting friendship with Taut.!* Among Behne’s earliest articles were
label: Paragraph

text: those in Die Hilfe—the weekly journal published by Friedrich Naumann, a
label: Paragraph

text: politician, former Protestant pastor, and one of the key organizers of the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund. Naumann had founded Die Hilfe in 1894 as the organ of the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gressive wing of the Christian-Social movement. He had been interested in
label: Paragraph

text: using the arts to improve the quality of products because he believed that
label: Paragraph

text: doing so “would raise the value of labor, improve the worker's status,
label: Paragraph

text: increase his joy in work, and thus reverse the trend to proletarianization
label: Paragraph

text: hitherto associated with the advance of capitalism.”"5 Together with the soci-
label: Paragraph

text: ologist Max Weber, with whom he was closely associated, Naumann rejected
label: Paragraph

text: the Marxist view that economics is the central factor in social change. Both
label: Paragraph

text: men stressed the plurality and interdependence of causes.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s name appears for the first time as a member of the Werkbund in
label: Paragraph

text: 1913, the year after he received his doctorate. Before World War 1 he published
label: Paragraph

text: articles on the work of Peter Behrens and Taut. His articles appeared in Der
label: Paragraph

text: Sturm, Die Welibiihne, Sozialistische Monatshefte, and Das neue Frankfurt,
label: Caption

text: among many other periodicals. He wrote frequently on the role of the museum
label: Paragraph

text: in the general education of the public and more specifically on the ambigu-
label: Paragraph

text: ous nature of the framed picture in the museum setting. Since the museum
label: Paragraph

text: imposes a change in context on all works of art, he saw the common concern
label: Paragraph

text: with “original” art as a false issue. In his essay “Das reproduktive Zeitalter”
label: Paragraph

text: (The reproductive era} of 1917, he seems to prefigure Walter Benjamin’s well-
label: Paragraph

text: known thesis about the effect of mass produced images on art.'¢ Behne was
label: Paragraph

text: also interested in advertising and its wide-ranging effects on culture: he
label: Paragraph

text: once referred to Mendelsohn’s urban buildings as Reklamearchitektur (adver-
label: Paragraph

text: tising architecture). He did not, however, see eye-to-eye with the prevailing
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund policy imposing aesthetic standards on all aspects of daily life.
label: Paragraph

text: Advertising, he wrote in 1924, was as central to a modern economy as
label: Paragraph

text: money, and any attempt to control it through aesthetic regulations was
label: Paragraph

text: bound to be counterproductive in that it would treat advertising as a purely
label: Paragraph

text: formal problem. On the one hand, Behne did not believe that using art to
label: Paragraph

text: mask a subject was necessarily good.'? On the other hand, he wrote about
label: Paragraph

text: films as art as early as 1921, and he included the important role of film in
label: Paragraph

text: his discussion of pedagogy.'®
label: Paragraph

text: As noted above, Behne’s first book, Zur neuen Kunst was published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1915 by Der Sturm, the major disseminator of contemporary, and particu-
label: Paragraph

text: larly Expressionist, art. An excerpt from the book titled “Expressionistische
label: Paragraph

text: Architektur” appeared in the magazine Der Sturm in the same year. This
label: Paragraph

text: essay was among the earliest attempts to define Expressionism, and it
label: Paragraph

text: certainly was the first to do so within the context of architecture. Behne’s
label: Paragraph

text: description of Expressionism was not narrowly Germanic or medievalizing,
label: Paragraph

text: and his essay included Cubism and Futurism as equally important aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of this contemporary expression.’
label: Paragraph

text: In 1915 Behne also wrote an article in Die Tat entitled “Der Hass der
label: Paragraph

text: Neutralen” (The hatred of the neutrals), in which he complained about the
label: Paragraph

text: lack of support for Germany during the early war years. He returned the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of an “avant-garde” to its original military meaning when he wrote that
label: Paragraph

text: those who did not commit themselves were fearful of the new. Behne was
label: Paragraph

text: hardly alone in this attitude. The sociologist Weber described the war as
label: Paragraph

text: “great and wonderful,” and Thomas Mann saw it as “purification, liberation
label: Paragraph

text: ...an immense hope.”2¢
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s position during the war years has led to a diverse set of assess-
label: Paragraph

text: ments concerning his political beliefs. lain Boyd Whyte in his otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally informative Bruno Taut and the Architecture of Activism, 1982,
label: Caption

text: uses this essay and Behne’s association with the Choriner Kreis (among
label: Paragraph

text: other things) to show that he (and Taut) were essentially conservative.?! Fol-
label: Paragraph

text: lowing the Marxist, or more correctly Stalinist, argument of Georg Lukacs in
label: Paragraph

text: his attack on Expressionism of 1934 (by this time he had become an apologist
label: Paragraph

text: for Stalinism), Whyte finds conservatism endemic. Lukacs viewed Expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sionism as counterrevolutionary because it was a product of imperialist cap-
label: Paragraph

text: italism and therefore responsible for fascism. According to the Lukacsian
label: Paragraph

text: formula, the association of Behne and Taut with the Choriner Kreis estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lishes them as conservative, because the group's back-to-nature component
label: Paragraph

text: can be regarded as part of the Wandervégel Movement, which began in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s. By the 1930s this movement was clearly an extension of the National
label: Paragraph

text: Socialists’ nationalism and racialism; however, before World War 1, it was
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps patriotic but not nationalist.”? As with the Werkbund, however,
label: Paragraph

text: political uniformity cannot be ascribed to the members of any large orga-
label: Paragraph

text: nization, By the same token, one cannot say that the Expressionists or mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernists were all liberal. A similar restrictive Lukacsian formula led Magdalena
label: Paragraph

text: Bushart in Der Geist der Gotik und die Expressionistische Kunst (The spirit of
label: Title

text: the Gothic and Expressionist art), 1990, to categorize Behne as an oppor-
label: Paragraph

text: tunist because of his later shift in political opinion.”? But not all changes of
label: Paragraph

text: attitude reflect ulterior motives. Walter Benjamin, for instance, who was
label: Paragraph

text: generally recognized as a Marxist in the 1920s, had participated in the Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: man youth movement before 1914.%4
label: Paragraph

text: Lukacs’s reductive argument was countered in the late 1930s by one of
label: Paragraph

text: his former friends, the Marxist philosopher Ernst Bloch (they had met in
label: Paragraph

text: Simmel’s seminar). Bloch wrote that Lukacs’s opinions were based primarily
label: Paragraph

text: on literary Expressionism, as opposed to painting and architecture. He
label: Paragraph

text: argued further that Expressionism did in fact question basic social values
label: Paragraph

text: and asserted the constructive value of utopianism. Bloch also found the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionists' inclusion of folk art from many countries more meaningful
label: Paragraph

text: than the Neoclassicism that Lukacs had endorsed.*® Most contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Marxist historians such as Manfredo Tafuri and Francesco Dal Co cite
label: Paragraph

text: only Lukacs and not Bloch, thereby overlooking the vigorous debate and dis-
label: Paragraph

text: agreements about a politically engaged art that took place in the 1920s and
label: Paragraph

text: 19308.” Possibly because of Lukacs’s influence on recent literary criticism,
label: Paragraph

text: his opinions about Expressionist literature have been carried over into the
label: Paragraph

text: other arts of the period with which, however, he was not as familiar.
label: Paragraph

text: Whyte is correct when he maintains that a shift in beliefs took place as
label: Paragraph

text: World War 1 progressed. Some, like Taut, became pacifists. Behne joined
label: Paragraph

text: the alternative service as a medical orderly during the war. As early as 1914
label: Paragraph

text: three of Behne's lectures were published by the educational committee of
label: Paragraph

text: the Social Democratic Party (spp), and he wrote for the party’s weekly, Die
label: Paragraph

text: neue Zeit.’” In 1917, on the other hand, he wrote a book that was published
label: Paragraph

text: under the auspices of the Diirerbund, a fairly conservative educational asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciation for the appreciation of art founded in 1902. In 1917 he also wrote an
label: Paragraph

text: essay in praise of the Russian Revolution.’8 It is clear that at the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: of his career his interest in a populist approach to art colored most of his
label: Paragraph

text: associations. However, sometime during these early years he joined the spp,
label: Paragraph

text: and in 1913 he had begun writing for Sozialistische Monatshefe, which publi-
label: Paragraph

text: cized the international socialist movement. After the war he joined the uspp,
label: Paragraph

text: the Independent Social Democratic Party and the schismatic left wing of the
label: Paragraph

text: majority Socialists; this group had been founded in 1917 to call for an end to
label: Paragraph

text: the war and to help politicize the labor force.29
label: Caption

text: Lukacs, in fact, had coupled his critique of Expressionism with an attack
label: Paragraph

text: on the uspp. In his opinion the uspn’s attitude toward revolution, like that of
label: Paragraph

text: the Expressionists, was half-hearted. Lukdcs’s scorn directed at Expression-
label: Paragraph

text: ists and the uspp reflects the uneasy alliance between these groups and the
label: Paragraph

text: Spartacists — from 1919 on the Communists (krp}—and their later extreme
label: Paragraph

text: doctrinal split. By the late 1920s the kpp and the uspp had become arch-
label: Paragraph

text: enemies. But in the last year of the war the Spartacists were loosely asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciated with the uspp,’° and in reality the uspp participated in the mislabeled
label: Paragraph

text: “Spartacus Uprising” of January 1919. Both the spp and the KPD were
label: Paragraph

text: working-class parties. The kpp, however, contained more unskilled and
label: Paragraph

text: unemployed workers. The parties’ respective social programs reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: differences in their makeups. The Social Democrats sought to develop
label: Paragraph

text: orthodox Marxism into a Volkssozialismus (popular socialism) and Kultur-
label: Paragraph

text: sozialismus (cultural socialism) within the capitalist system; the Com-
label: Paragraph

text: munists, however, demanded radical change and regarded any reform as
label: Paragraph

text: illusory. Much of the energy of the labor movement was dissipated by the
label: Paragraph

text: intense enmity between these parties. After 1928 the change of policy of
label: Paragraph

text: the Soviet Communist Party and the Comintern imposed complete sepa-
label: Paragraph

text: ratism on the xpp, which became openly confrontational with the spp.?! If
label: Paragraph

text: one talks about the fate of the Weimar Republic and the responsibility for
label: Paragraph

text: the onset of fascism, a great deal of blame can be meted out not just to con-
label: Paragraph

text: servatives but also to the Communists for their refusal to form an alliance
label: Paragraph

text: with the Socialists.
label: Paragraph

text: Lukécs’s simultaneous attack of Expressionism and the uspp in 1934
label: Paragraph

text: must therefore be viewed not just in contrast with Bloch’s response but
label: Paragraph

text: even more as an instance of the hard-left approach of the German xpp and
label: Paragraph

text: its ongoing internecine struggle with the competing workers’ party, the
label: Paragraph

text: Social Democrats. By the end of the war Behne had become unquestion-
label: Paragraph

text: ably associated with the uspp. In rg19 he complained in an article titled
label: Paragraph

text: “Unsere moralische Krisis” (Our moral crisis), published in the Soziali-
label: Paragraph

text: stische Monatshefte, that nothing had changed and that there had really been
label: Paragraph

text: no break with old attitudes of nationalist arrogance.}? At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: Behne, although often critical of German society, retained the Social Demo-
label: Paragraph

text: crats’ belief in the possiblity of reform. While some of his books were
label: Paragraph

text: addressed to a cultural elite, many more of his publications in the 1920s
label: Paragraph

text: were directed to a larger audience. Among these were his introductions
label: Paragraph

text: to art and contemporary art respectively, both published in 1925 by the
label: Paragraph

text: Arbeiter-Jugend Verlag, Die Uberfahrt am Schreckenstein: Eine Einfithrung
label: Title

text: in die Kunst (The passage to the Schreckenstein: An introduction to art) and
label: Paragraph

text: Von Kunst zur Gestaltung: Eine Einfithrung in die moderne Kunst (From art
label: Title

text: to design: An introduction to modern art). His deep commitment as a
label: Paragraph

text: teacher to the Volkshochschule Movement is another indication of his general
label: Paragraph

text: agreement with the Social Democrats’ attempt to develop a popular and cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural socialism.*?

text: Does Modernism Equal Functionalism?
label: Title

text: For many architectural historians, even those who are well acquainted with
label: Paragraph

text: German developments in the 1920s, Modernism and functionalism have
label: Paragraph

text: become nearly synonymous.** Within the comparatively brief period of
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism, however, functionalism assumed many guises. Although it is
label: Paragraph

text: not within the scope of this essay to do justice to the complexity of function-
label: Paragraph

text: alist beliefs in modern architecture, some arguments about functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: are useful to consider in order to understand both the underlying conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of functionalism in the 19208 and the considerable misunderstand-
label: Paragraph

text: ings that have become embedded in postmodern discussions.
label: Paragraph

text: Two extreme positions regarding functionalism help to introduce suc-
label: Paragraph

text: cinctly the conflicting issues of the history of the term and current reac-
label: Paragraph

text: tions to it. Characteristic of the positive view of functionalism in the 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: is Edward Robert de Zurko’s excessively broad and uncritical history Origins
label: Paragraph
