label: Caption

text: against functionalism is David Watkin’s rather narrowly conceived Morality
label: Paragraph

text: and Architecture, 1977. The shared assumption in both works is that func-
label: Paragraph

text: tionalism is synonymous with Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Using a rather circular argument, de Zurko writes that “the literature
label: Paragraph

text: of functionalism consists largely of the writings of recognized functional-
label: Paragraph

text: ists (such as Horatio Greenough, Louis Sullivan, and Taut).”3* Whereas de
label: Paragraph

text: Zurko’s book is perhaps too inclusive regarding ideas of purpose and utility,
label: Paragraph

text: Watkin’s tone is that of a postmodern scold. He belittles Le Corbusier's Vers
label: Paragraph

text: une architecture, 1923, because, in Watkin's words, “What is simple, suppos-
label: Paragraph

text: edly functional, and materialistic in aim, light in colour, and immediately
label: Paragraph

text: apprehensible in form enjoys advantages in terms of health and morality
label: Paragraph

text: over other different or more complex solutions. Thus it must be imposed on
label: Paragraph

text: society as soon as possible if we are to avoid revolution.” He goes on to insist
label: Paragraph

text: that the apocalyptic overtones of Le Corbusier’s functionalist argument were
label: Paragraph

text: later exaggerated by Taut in his Modern Architecture, 1929, and cites the fol-
label: Paragraph

text: lowing passage from Taut to prove his point:
label: Paragraph

text: If everything is founded on sound efficiency, this efficiency itself, or rather its
label: Paragraph

text: utility, will form its own aesthetic law. A building must be beautiful when seen
label: Paragraph

text: from outside if it reflects all these qualities... The architect who achieves this
label: Paragraph

text: task becomes a creator of an ethical and social character; the people who use the
label: Paragraph

text: building for any purpose, will, through the structure of the house, be brought
label: Paragraph

text: to a better behaviour in their mutual dealings and relationship with each
label: Paragraph

text: other. Thus architecture becomes the creator of new social observances.**
label: Paragraph

text: If Watkin himself takes on a moralizing voice in his critique of moralizing
label: Paragraph

text: theories (in this instance a Puginian trust in social control through architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture), de Zurko is more open-minded than most modernist historians in his
label: Paragraph

text: belief that “modern discussions of functionalism show a dual approach: the
label: Paragraph

text: rational and the poetic.” He cautions also that “the frequency of statements
label: Paragraph

text: by modern architects regarding functionalism indicates that functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: is neither a clear and unchallenged law of architecture nor a spent force, but
label: Paragraph

text: a vital concept requiring clarification.”
label: Paragraph

text: Important for understanding modern functionalism and Behne’s attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to categorize the various tendencies is de Zurko’s discussion of two major
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century functionalist trends: the mechanical and the organic
label: Title

text: analogies. The former uses machines as a paradigm for aesthetic theory and
label: Paragraph

text: is a response to the Industrial Revolution. Although the latter trend draws
label: Paragraph

text: its references from nature and the former employs models of mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: production, both could be invoked together. A clear and early example is the
label: Paragraph

text: theory of the American sculptor Horatio Greenough, who in 1843 proposed
label: Paragraph

text: a functionalist approach to architecture in order to create what he thought
label: Paragraph

text: of as a tabula rasa, or hedge against the influence of the older European
label: Paragraph

text: styles. He believed that functionalism could foster an indigenous American
label: Paragraph

text: approach to design and recommended, “Let us consult nature, and in the
label: Paragraph

text: assurance that she will disclose a mine richer than was ever dreamed of by
label: Paragraph

text: the Greeks.” He went on to say that “the law of adaptation is the fundamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tal law of nature in all structure.” Together with this organic justification,
label: Paragraph

text: Greenough drew a parallel between natural selection and the production of
label: Paragraph

text: man-made artifacts in general and machines in particular, “If we compare
label: Paragraph

text: the form of a newly invented machine with the perfected type of the same
label: Paragraph

text: instrument, we observe, as we trace it through the phases of improvement,
label: Paragraph

text: how weight is shaken off where strength is less needed, how functions are
label: Paragraph

text: made to approach without impeding each other, how straight becomes curved,
label: Paragraph

text: and the curve is straightened, till the straggling and cumbersome machine
label: Paragraph

text: becomes the compact effective and beautiful engine.”*
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to the organic and mechanical paradigm, Greenough, through
label: Paragraph

text: his close relationship with Ralph Waldo Emerson, gave his ideas an ethical
label: Paragraph

text: dimension as well. Behne would also address all three functional concepts
label: Paragraph

text: present in Modernism — the organic, the mechanical, and the social — but
label: Paragraph

text: whereas he described the first two in his role as a historian of the 19208, he
label: Paragraph

text: only advocated a type including a social dimension. His advocacy of a social
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism, in fact, resembles Louis Sullivan's polemics.
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s dictum “form follows function,” stated first in 1888, employed
label: Paragraph

text: two components of Greenough’s functionalism. Its Lamarckian organi-
label: Paragraph

text: cism is the most evident, and disregarding Greenough's mechanical anal-
label: Paragraph

text: ogy, Sullivan gave the ethical aspect of functionalism greater importance.
label: Paragraph

text: Although initially indebted to Transcendentalism as much as to Greenough,
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan came under the influence of Chicago School pragmatic realism
label: Paragraph

text: and John Dewey’s utilitarian instrumentalism in the 1890s. These philoso-
label: Paragraph

text: phies assumed a complex interrelationship between human thought and
label: Paragraph

text: action and the environment. This interrelationship contrasts with the simple
label: Paragraph

text: behaviorist model of Pugin, in which the environment affects human action
label: Paragraph

text: but not vice versa. Hugh Dalziel Duncan explains the Chicago School and
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan's dictum thus, “Forms arise in attempts to solve problems in social
label: Paragraph

text: action, form and function are real, not because of their relationship to an
label: Paragraph

text: essence outside of or beyond action, but within action in society”?
label: Paragraph

text: The distinctly utilitarian ethics of “form follows function” do not seem
label: Paragraph

text: to have—on the surface at least—a direct relationship with Central Euro-
label: Paragraph

text: pean ideas in the early twentieth century. However, Beline’s stress on the
label: Paragraph

text: social implications of functionalism, despite his rejection of “utilitarian-
label: Paragraph

text: ism” as he understood it, cannot be divorced altogether from the social
label: Paragraph

text: meaning of utilitarianism or from Sullivan’s understanding of function as a
label: Paragraph

text: social tool.
label: Paragraph

text: Because “form follows function” is such an easy-to-recall, alliterative,
label: Paragraph

text: and concise phrase, it has unfortunately been remembered far too often. In
label: Paragraph

text: popular usage throughout the second half of the twentieth century, it has
label: Paragraph

text: usually been forgotten that the phrase was coined by Sullivan, and today it is
label: Paragraph

text: frequently associated with European Modernism in general or, just as often,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Bauhaus specifically. In fact, “form follows function” and “Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism” have become imprecise, interchangeable clichés that are
label: Paragraph

text: used either descriptively by modernists or critically by postmodernists as a
label: Paragraph

text: presumed shorthand for Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: n Hitchcock and Johnson's The International Style—so important for
label: Paragraph

text: introducing an American audience to European Modernism — this confu-
label: Paragraph

text: sion had not yet occurred. Hitchcock and Johnson, in fact, tried to discredit
label: Paragraph

text: modern functionalism for its lack of aesthetic concerns:
label: Paragraph

text: Il
label: Title

text: Some modern critics and groups of architects both in Europe and in America
label: Paragraph

text: deny that the aesthetic element in architecture is important, or even that it
label: Paragraph

text: exists. All aesthetic principles of style are to them meaningless and unreal. This
label: Paragraph

text: new conception, that building is science and not art, developed as an exaggera-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the idea of functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: In its most generally accepted form the idea of function is sufficiently elas-
label: Paragraph

text: tic. It derives its sanctions from both Greek and Gothic architecture, for in the
label: Paragraph

text: temple as well as in the cathedral the aesthetic expression is based on structure
label: Paragraph

text: and function.*”
label: Paragraph

text: They held Hannes Meyer, in particular, responsible for a contemporary doc-
label: Paragraph

text: trinaire functionalism, because he was an “anti-aesthetic functionalist” who
label: Paragraph

text: claimed that the basis of all design must be economic.
label: Paragraph

text: Lewis Mumford in an essay of 1951, “Function and Expression in Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture,” saw the failure of modern architecture, by contrast, to be its lack of
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic communication. He identified an excessive reliance on a machine
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic and a misunderstanding of “form follows function” as the central
label: Paragraph

text: problem in the later development of Modernism:
label: Paragraph

text: Now all this is not to say that the doctrine that form follows function was a
label: Paragraph

text: misleading one. What was false and meretricious were the narrow applications
label: Paragraph

text: that were made of this formula. Actually, functionalism is subject to two main
label: Paragraph

text: modifications. The first is that we must not take function solely in a mechani-
label: Paragraph

text: cal sense, as applying only to the physical functions of the building. Certainly
label: Paragraph

text: new technical facilities and mechanical functions required new forms; but so,
label: Paragraph

text: likewise, did new social purposes and new psychological insights.*!
label: Paragraph

text: For Mumford the modern period is an “age of deep psychological explo-
label: Paragraph

text: ration and heightened social responsibility.” It is not just the age of Albert
label: Paragraph

text: Einstein, Henry Bessemer, and Frederick Taylor but also the age of Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Darwin, Henri Bergson, Sigmund Freud, and Pyotr Alekseyevich Kropotkin.
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford’s analysis is similar to that of Joseph Hudnut in his essay “The
label: Paragraph

text: Post-Modern House,” 1945.*? Hudnut was then the dean of Harvard’s influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ential Graduate School of Design and was responsible for bringing Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: to Harvard. He criticized the use of a dogmatic functionalism and struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural invention for its own sake. As early as 1931 (that is, before Hitchcock
label: Paragraph

text: and Johnson), he had complained that the doctrine of functionalism could
label: Paragraph

text: be obfuscating and mystifying if a rigid utilitarianism became the sole
label: Paragraph

text: principle of design. He regarded as naive the belief that beauty is automati-
label: Paragraph

text: cally created by building logically, the shibboleth of “form follows function.”
label: Paragraph

text: If this were correct, no school of architecture would have to concern itself
label: Paragraph

text: with the teaching of beauty; it would be enough to teach economics, busi-
label: Paragraph

text: ness, and the cost of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: The present-day misunderstanding of modernist functionalism does not
label: Paragraph

text: in fact spring from either Taut’s or Hannes Meyer's conception; it is based
label: Paragraph

text: on an overly narrow definition of function as a single issue that is presumed
label: Paragraph

text: to be a practical design response within a specific building, one that does
label: Paragraph

text: not seem to embrace environmental, social, or economic factors. In this
label: Paragraph

text: later, simplistic version of functionalism, biological and utilitarian ideas
label: Paragraph

text: have become not only hopelessly abbreviated, frozen, and canonical but also
label: Paragraph

text: nearly meaningless.
label: Paragraph

text: One problem with interpreting functionalism as if it were a law or
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical theorem (the belief that there is indeed a specific form for
label: Paragraph

text: each possible function) is that it is based on a fundamental misappre-
label: Paragraph

text: hension of design procedures. In truth, a single function — if it can ever be
label: Paragraph

text: completely segregated conceptually from all other functions —can be inter-
label: Paragraph

text: preted by the architect in many appropriate formal expressions. Never-
label: Paragraph

text: theless, “form follows function” in its popular conception may be difficult
label: Paragraph

text: to dislodge because it provides a semblance of rules in an area where there
label: Paragraph

text: are none.
label: Paragraph

text: Not all architectural histories that address functionalism are as extreme
label: Paragraph

text: as de Zurko’s in their apparent unpolemical neutrality or as hotly polemi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal as Watkin’s. For instance, Heinrich Klotz in The History of Postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, 1988, makes a fair assessment of the difference between the
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of classical Modernism and a later “vulgar” or “doctrinaire”
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism. He even takes time to discuss the less well-known organic
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of Haring, a form of modernist functionalism that Behne
label: Paragraph

text: also deals with at length. The postmodern reaction against Modernism —as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the consequent tendency to present Modernism in an overly simplis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic form —has been most apparent in the Anglo-American sphere, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: elsewhere attitudes have reflected a calmer evolutionary approach. In this
label: Paragraph

text: context it is significant that Klotz’s book, when it was first published in Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many in 1984, was called Moderne und Postmoderne: Architektur der Gegen-
label: Paragraph

text: wart. The German title suggests that Modernism and postmodernism are
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously present in contemporary architecture; in the title of the
label: Paragraph

text: American version Modernism has been banished.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas de Zurko described the progress of functionalism uncritically,
label: Paragraph

text: Colquhoun in his Essays in Architectural Criticism: Modern Architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: Historical Change, 1981, assessed the possible meaning of functionalism in a
label: Paragraph

text: few words but with far greater cogency:
label: Paragraph

text: Positivism, in separating pure instrumentality from meaning, impelled
label: Paragraph

text: architecture simultaneously toward eclecticism and functionalism. Ever since
label: Paragraph

text: the late eighteenth century, architecture has oscillated between two poles of
label: Paragraph

text: thought: that according to which all styles are possible and that according to
label: Paragraph

text: which all styles are forbidden — between synchronic and diachronic relativism.
label: Paragraph

text: But diachronic relativism — the belief in the continuous evolution of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural form—can be seen, from another point of view, as the continuation of
label: Paragraph

text: the eighteenth-century search for the origins of architecture. There is still the
label: Paragraph

text: sense of a return to the primitive statement unsullied by the historical accumu-
label: Paragraph

text: lation of metaphor. We see then that the origins of modern functionalism lie in
label: Paragraph

text: a very complex intermixture of the notion of architecture as relative and evolu-
label: Paragraph

text: tionary and the notion of architecture as based on natural law.**
label: Paragraph

text: Equally suggestive, Stanford Anderson in his essay “The Fiction of Func-
label: Paragraph

text: tion,” 1987, has argued that “‘functionalism’ is a weak concept, inadequate
label: Paragraph

text: for the characterization or analysis of any architecture.” He continues: “It
label: Paragraph

text: may be useful to recognize ‘functionalism’ to the extent that one can find
label: Paragraph

text: some naive functionalist arguments to contrast with Hitchcock and John-
label: Paragraph

text: son’s antifunctionalist rhetoric. However, any serious examination of the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings at issue will reveal that none of them, whatever the surround-
label: Paragraph

text: ing rhetoric, can be explained functionally. It was a fiction that function
label: Paragraph

text: provided a crucial line of demarcation within modern architecture.”*5 He
label: Paragraph

text: goes on to describe functionalism in modern architecture as a specific form
label: Paragraph

text: of fiction—not a lie but a storyline that was used to describe a vision of
label: Paragraph

text: the world that is richer and broader than the postmodern, truncated notion
label: Paragraph

text: of functionalism projected onto Modernism. Of course, postmodernists
label: Paragraph

text: demonized Modernism in the same manner that modernists demonized
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century eclecticism — another form of fictionalizing the past, in
label: Paragraph

text: this case with Gothic horror stories. Anderson's suggestion for studying the
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist storyline of the modernists will allow us to comprehend their
label: Paragraph

text: understanding and self-presentation vis-a-vis theory and architecture in its
label: Paragraph

text: widest implications. Modernist texts need to be examined, therefore, in
label: Paragraph

text: order to discover both their constructive and constructed fiction.
label: Paragraph

text: To date, a general awareness of specific modernist books is inadequate,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps because so few of these texts of the 19208 have been translated.
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s Modern Architecture was the only one of the German books of this time
label: Paragraph

text: that also appeared in English. Le Corbusier's Vers une architecture, translated
label: Paragraph

text: into English in 1927, is really his own vision for a new architecture and is
label: Paragraph

text: not about the work and ideas of his colleagues. In addition, many of the cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tral texts of this period are not readily accessible. They are usually found in
label: Paragraph

text: special collections of only the best libraries. It is not surprising, therefore,
label: Paragraph

text: that the historically important International Style or Giedion’s Space, Time,
label: Paragraph

text: and Architecture, 1941, still form the basis for understanding Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: The Background to the Debate in Germany:
label: Paragraph

text: The Structure and Politics of Education As a Competitive System
label: Title

text: During the 1920s Germany became the center of Modernism in architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. The creation of the Bauhaus in 1919; the Werkbund Ausstellung “Die
label: Paragraph

text: Wohnung” (a housing exposition held at Weissenhof in Stuttgart) in 1927
label: Paragraph

text: (with an international group of architects that included Mies, Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: and Oud); and the meeting of cram 11 (Congrés Internationaux d’Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture Moderne) in 1929 in Frankfurt are only a few of the more publicized
label: Paragraph

text: events. Germany’s centrality in the architectural avant-garde is not entirely
label: Paragraph

text: due to the presumed liberalism of the Weimar Republic, with which the
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary tendencies of the decade are often equated.
label: Paragraph

text: The prelude to Germany (and Central Europe) becoming the interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional focus of modernist theory and debate must be sought, at least in part,
label: Paragraph

text: in the exceptionally competitive and pluralistic educational system estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished in the course of the nineteenth century and fully in place by the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the century.*°
label: Paragraph

text: This was not the case in France. The Académie Royale de Peinture et
label: Paragraph

text: de Sculpture and the Académie Royale d’Architecture (which merged in
label: Paragraph

text: the nineteenth century to become the Ecole des Beaux-Arts) had been cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tralized under Louis xrv in order to preernpt the power of the guilds.‘”
label: Paragraph

text: Similarly, the Ecole Polytechnique, founded in the late eighteenth century,
label: Paragraph

text: followed in the tradition of the older Ecole des Ponts et Chaussées (School of
label: Paragraph

text: bridges and roadways). Although both the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and the
label: Paragraph

text: Ecole Polytechnique underwent considerable restructuring over the years,
label: Paragraph

text: neither was decentralized until after the student protests of 1968.
label: Paragraph

text: The difference in Germany was not the quality of the schools as such but
label: Paragraph

text: the structural variation determined by the country’s political history. In Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many, for instance, the struggle for control between the older guild system
label: Paragraph

text: and the newer academies was not changed by the fiat of a powerful monarch
label: Paragraph

text: as it had been in France. Debates about the respective merit of each contin-
label: Paragraph

text: ued into the early 1920s and the beginning years of the Bauhaus, when the
label: Paragraph

text: school vacillated between being a lodge for artisans and an elite academy
label: Paragraph

text: turning out designers for industry.
label: Paragraph

text: More importantly, because Germany consisted of a large number of inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendent principalities, the growth and development of architectural edu-
label: Paragraph

text: cation differed from region to region. In the late eighteenth century, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, Prussia experimented with architectural instruction carried out
label: Paragraph

text: in an art academy, but apparently because of an overemphasis on rules of
label: Paragraph

text: taste and purely ceremonial expression, a separate school of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was founded in 1799, the Bauakademie in Berlin. Here construction and
label: Paragraph

text: civic planning were given greater importance. The Berlin Bauakademie was
label: Paragraph

text: united with the Gewerbeakademie (Crafts academy) in 1879 to form the
label: Paragraph

text: Technische Hochschule (Polytechnic school). In the course of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century separate polytechnic schools, rather than architecture depart-
label: Paragraph

text: ments attached to art academies, became the most prestigious schools of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, although those within art academies continued into the twenti-
label: Paragraph

text: eth century. A polytechnic school was founded in Karlsruhe in 1825, in Dres-
label: Paragraph

text: den in 1838, in Stuttgart in 1840, in Hannover in 1862, in Darmstadt in
label: Paragraph

text: 1864, in Munich in 1865, and in Aachen in 1870. Still others were founded
label: Paragraph

text: after Germany’s unification in 1871.*8
label: Caption

text: Even after unification, polytechnic schools remained extraordinarily var-
label: Paragraph

text: ied. Local traditions, once established, were not readily surrendered. Further-
label: Paragraph

text: more, member states were not treated equally. The larger southern states,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the kingdomis of Wiirttemberg and Bavaria, had exacted special priv-
label: Paragraph

text: ileges not extended to other states. At any rate, the control of civil liberties,
label: Paragraph

text: the police, and education belonged to the separate states, not the federal gov-
label: Paragraph

text: ernment. Despite Prussia’s attempt in the 1880s to establish educational
label: Paragraph

text: standards for polytechnic schools in the Reich, it is not surprising that
label: Paragraph

text: schools continued to differ in their pedagogical emphases, nor that those in
label: Paragraph

text: the southern states, which had had a strong anti-Prussian history before
label: Paragraph

text: 1871, were the most liberal institutions. Both the Technische Hochschule in
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart and that in Munich, for example, were less pedantic in their educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion than the Berlin polytechnic school, which emphasized memorization
label: Paragraph

text: and extremely long examinations. The schools in Karlsruhe, Darmstadt, and
label: Paragraph

text: Dresden were more middle-of-the-road, somewhere between Berlin’s con-
label: Paragraph

text: servative institution and the more liberal ones in Stuttgart and Munich.*?
label: Paragraph

text: The most important unifying factor among the various polytechnic
label: Paragraph

text: schools was of course the German language, allowing professors and stu-
label: Paragraph

text: dents to move from one school to another. Gropius, for instance, attended
label: Paragraph

text: both the Berlin and the Munich Technische Hochschule. For this reason
label: Paragraph

text: students and teachers were kept aware of pedagogical differences. Where
label: Paragraph

text: students were unable to influence curricula, they could certainly vote with
label: Paragraph

text: their feet. Add to this matrix the polytechnic schools in German-speaking
label: Paragraph

text: countries — among them, those in Vienna, Prague, Graz, Brno, and Zurich —
label: Paragraph

text: and one can see the obvious potential for a lively competition.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, Germany, like most other countries, continued to rely
label: Paragraph

text: on the older apprenticeship system. But unlike other countries, it also had
label: Paragraph

text: a Bauschule (building school) or Baugewerksschule (building trade school); in
label: Paragraph

text: 1957 such institutions were given the more impressive name Ingenieur-
label: Paragraph

text: schulen fiir Bauwesen (engineering schools for the construction trade). The
label: Paragraph

text: polytechnic school was the most academically structured of these options,
label: Paragraph

text: requiring graduation from a Gymnasium, the higher secondary school
label: Paragraph

text: attended only by those who plan to go on to a university. A diploma from
label: Paragraph

text: a polytechnic school was also the prerequisite for administrative jobs with
label: Paragraph

text: the governmental bureaucracy. In this respect, the German polytechnic
label: Paragraph

text: school was comparable to attending the Ecole des Beaux-Arts or Ecole Poly-
label: Paragraph

text: technique in France.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bauschule, on the other hand, required only previous work as an
label: Paragraph

text: apprentice. In Germany compulsory education ends at age fourteen with
label: Paragraph

text: education in a Volksschule. For most of those entering an apprenticeship
label: Paragraph

text: system, however, education continues in a “trade school” where classroom
label: Paragraph

text: attendance is combined with on-the-job training. The Bauschule was close
label: Paragraph

text: in conception to the trade schools set up for apprentices in other fields.
label: Paragraph

text: Courses were usually given during the winter months when there was little
label: Paragraph

text: construction, and summers were spent as an apprentice. The Bauschule,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore, combined academic and apprenticeship training. It was in effect
label: Paragraph

text: a part-time academy that retained the advantages of practical experience.
label: Paragraph

text: The Munich Bauschule, the oldest, was founded in 1820, and the Weimar
label: Paragraph

text: Bauschule was founded by Goethe in 1828.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early twentieth century, architectural education had attained a
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchic configuration with the greatest prestige residing in the most
label: Paragraph

text: academic training. Nonetheless, it was entirely possible for architecture stu-
label: Paragraph

text: dents to avail themselves of ail three systems — polytechnic school, Bau-
label: Paragraph

text: schule, or apprenticeship — really four systems if one includes the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: departments in art academies. Thus the picture became even more cormn-
label: Paragraph

text: plex and competitive. Taut, for example, studied at a Bauschule, then was
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticed to several architects, and thereafter attended selected courses at
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlin Technische Hochschule. Given the diversity of schools within the
label: Paragraph

text: Reich —as well as the ability of students to attend several schools of the
label: Paragraph

text: same academic rank in different states and to participate in the various hier-
label: Paragraph

text: archic levels of architectural training —it becomes extremely difficult for
label: Paragraph

text: the historian to make succinct generalizations about architectural education
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany. One can only speculate that its basic structural complexity
label: Paragraph

text: exposed young architects to a variety of competing approaches and philoso-
label: Paragraph

text: phies, which in turn may account for the intensive debates surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the early twentieth century. The political change after 1918
label: Paragraph

text: would not have made an immediate impact, because the structure of these
label: Paragraph

text: competing and interrelated pedagogical systems did not change drastically.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, the modernists of the 1920s were all educated before 1918, at a
label: Paragraph

text: time when these varied educational systems were all in place.
label: Paragraph

text: A comparison of two influential architects and mentors, Behrens and
label: Paragraph

text: Theodor Fischer, can perhaps explain why certain architects became impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant teachers for the generation that came into prominence in the 1920s and
label: Paragraph

text: how these teachers were affected by their own varied regional and educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tional backgrounds. Today, Behrens is still unfortunately seen as a “proto-
label: Paragraph

text: modernist” to whom Gropius, Mies, and Le Corbusier were all apprenticed.
label: Paragraph

text: As Stanford Anderson has pointed out, this definition of Behrens is a kind
label: Paragraph

text: of “back-forrnation” introduced by such historians as Nikolaus Pevsner and
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock;3° they saw Behrens through the work of his pupils and decided
label: Paragraph

text: that he was the originator of modern industrial forms. A better case can be
label: Paragraph

text: made, however, for viewing Behrens as an influential, if somewhat conser-
label: Paragraph

text: vative, architect who received important commissions from German indus-
label: Paragraph

text: try as well as from the Reich. His case is also interesting for demonstrating
label: Paragraph

text: the shift from aristocratic to industrial, corporate patronage of crafts and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture — symptomatic of Germany’s late industrialization, which was
label: Paragraph

text: burgeoning in the early twentieth century and transforming the country into
label: Paragraph

text: one of Europe’s foremost manufacturing centers.
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s education as an architect was of the most unconventional sort,
label: Paragraph

text: even in the context of the German pedagogical system. After receiving his
label: Paragraph

text: training as a painter, he worked in Munich, where in 1897 he became one
label: Paragraph

text: of the cofounders of the Vereinigte Werkstitten fiir Kunst im Handwerk
label: Caption

text: (United workshops for art in craft}, one of the several reformist arts and crafts
label: Paragraph

text: associations that took their cue from the English Arts and Crafts Movement.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1899 Behrens was one of seven artists invited by Grand Duke Ernst
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig of Hesse to become a member of the Darmstadt Artists’ Colony.
label: Paragraph

text: Because Ernst Ludwig was Queen Victoria’s grandson, he had made many
label: Paragraph

text: trips to England, where he had come in direct contact with the English Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts Movement, and he had commissioned M. H. Baillie Scott and
label: Paragraph

text: C. R. Ashbee to design rooms for him in Darmstadt. The Darmstadt Artists’
label: Paragraph

text: Colony was the only one of such turn-of-the-century ventures to be orga-
label: Paragraph

text: nized by an aristocratic patron, as opposed to the artists themselves. On the
label: Paragraph

text: Mathildenhohe, a hill overlooking the city, Ernst Ludwig wanted to establish
label: Paragraph

text: a “New Athens” in order to compete with nearby, more established cultural
label: Paragraph

text: centers. The artists were paid a salary and were expected to produce a Volks-
label: Paragraph

text: kultur. Their communal studio building, designed by the Austrian Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Maria Olbrich (the only architect in residence), was initially called the
label: Paragraph

text: Arbeitshaus (house of work) and later the Ernst-Ludwig-Haus. The location
label: Paragraph

text: of such an exclusive colony on the Mathildenhéhe— above both city and
label: Paragraph

text: palace, inverting the traditional hierarchy — vividly revealed the grand duke’s
label: Paragraph

text: high regard for the arts. It was an arrangement that remains, nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: intrinsically hierarchic. It simply placed the artist at the top of the pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: in place of the ruler.
label: Paragraph

text: If Ernst Ludwig expected a trickle-down effect from his New Athens,
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture and crafts exhibited on the Mathildenhdhe never fostered
label: Paragraph

text: a Volkskultur. On the contrary, some contemporary critics saw only an
label: Paragraph

text: expression of luxury in the form of a Gesamtkunstwerk. In 1901, the year of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mathildenhéhe’s first exhibition, a deficit of 300,000 Marks was in-
label: Paragraph

text: curred by the Artists’ Colony; this huge amount indicates that the artists
label: Paragraph

text: were living like princes in the grand duke’s not-so-rich Hesse.5! Similarly,
label: Paragraph

text: the Wiener Werkstatte went through a series of near-bankruptcies and
label: Paragraph

text: bailouts by wealthy patrons.%? This is not to question the beauty of many
label: Paragraph

text: designs made by the Darmstadt group or the Wiener Werkstatte but rather
label: Paragraph

text: their ability to bring their reforms to a wider audience as they intended. If
label: Paragraph

text: they had studied the English Arts and Crafts development more diligently,
label: Paragraph

text: they might have also discovered that William Morris had already encoun-
label: Paragraph

text: tered the problem of crafts production as something only the well-to-do
label: Paragraph

text: could afford.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the Artists’ Colony’s shortcomings, Behrens’s contact with
label: Paragraph

text: this group was important for his subsequent career change. At Darmstadt,
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens was the only artist who was allowed to design his own house; all
label: Paragraph

text: other buildings were designed by Olbrich. Without even an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticeship, Behrens made the transition from painting and arts and
label: Paragraph

text: crafts to architecture. He left Darmstadt in 1903 to take over the directorship
label: Paragraph

text: of the Kunstgewerbeschule (Arts and crafts school) in Diisseldorf. During
label: Paragraph

text: his Diisseldorf period Behrens met the wealthy, young Karl Ernst Osthaus,
label: Paragraph

text: who quickly replaced Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig as a more “modern” patron
label: Paragraph

text: of the arts and architecture. Osthaus came from a banking and industrialist
label: Paragraph

text: family and at the age of twenty-two had inherited 65 million Marks. He
label: Paragraph

text: established the Folkwang Museum in Hagen, an exhibition space for con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary art with an interior designed by Henry van de Velde. Between 1904
label: Paragraph

text: and 1912 Behrens designed eight projects for Osthaus, including a plan of
label: Paragraph

text: 1907 for Hagen-Eppenhausen, a garden suburb. Osthaus also became closely
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the Werkbund and in 1909 helped to create the Deutsches
label: Paragraph

text: Museum fiir Kunst im Handel und Gewerbe (German museum for art in
label: Title

text: trade and craft), in effect a Werkbund museum for traveling exhibitions.
label: Paragraph

text: With Osthaus’s patronage Hagen became a new cultural center, significantly
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of the industrial Ruhr district. In 1907 Behrens was named
label: Paragraph

text: the chief architect and designer of the az, then Germany’s foremost manu-
label: Paragraph

text: facturer of electrical products, which had its headquarters in Berlin. His fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tories for the arc and his designs of the company’s electric products were, if
label: Paragraph

text: not frank industrial expressions, symbolic expressions of industrial might.
label: Paragraph

text: It was during this period that Gropius, Mies, and Le Corbusier were
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticed to Behrens (not all at the same time). Each arrived with a differ-
label: Paragraph

text: ent background, rather characteristic of any group of architects in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: at the time. Gropius had the most formal education with four years of
label: Paragraph

text: schooling at two different polytechnic schools. Mies had gone through sev-
label: Paragraph

text: eral apprenticeships before joining Behrens, and Le Corbusier had attended
label: Paragraph

text: an arts and crafts school at La Chaux-de-Fonds in the Swiss Jura, where he
label: Paragraph

text: had initially learned to engrave watches. He arrived in Berlin, however, after
label: Paragraph

text: an apprenticeship with Auguste and Gustave Perret in Paris. Behrens was
label: Paragraph

text: not much their senior in terms of actual building experience, yet all chose to
label: Paragraph

text: work for this “artist-architect” who had an ability to evoke powerful images.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier in his report on German crafts and architecture, published in
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland in 1912, writes that Behrens’s aEG Turbine Factory was referred
label: Paragraph

text: to as a “cathedral of labor,” suggesting perhaps the reason for Behrens’s
label: Paragraph

text: rapid progression from high art at the Mathildenhohe to industrial image-
label: Paragraph

text: making in Berlin.*’ Behne would later take issue with Behrens as a modernist.
label: Paragraph

text: Though less well known today, even among architectural historians,
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer had a greater reputation as an architect and teacher than Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: before 1914. Le Corbusier first set out for Munich hoping to work for Fischer,
label: Paragraph

text: and only when Fischer did not have a place for him in his office did he ven-
label: Paragraph

text: ture on to Berlin in 1910 (with recommendations and letters of introduction
label: Paragraph

text: from Fischer). During this period Le Corbusier also met with Hermann
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius, Osthaus, Bruno Paul, Wolf Dohrn, and Heinrich Tessenow, all
label: Paragraph

text: among the more recognized figures of the early Werkbund.5+ Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: may have preferred to work with Fischer because he dealt with issues of city
label: Paragraph

text: planning and was much better and more conventionally trained as an archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect than Behrens. Fischer had been a student at the Munich Technische
label: Paragraph

text: Hochschule and served an apprenticeship under Paul Wallot, the architect
label: Paragraph

text: of the Reichstag in Berlin. In 1893 Fischer established himself as a practic-
label: Paragraph

text: ing architect in Munich. He moved to Stuttgart in 1901 when he received an
label: Paragraph

text: offer to teach at the Technische Hochschule there. He returned to Munich in
label: Paragraph

text: 1909 and taught at the Munich Technische Hochschule until 1928. Among
label: Paragraph

text: his many students and apprentices were Taut, Mendelsohn, Dominikus
label: Paragraph

text: Béhm, Haring, Oud, Ernst May, Alois Welzenbacher, Fred Forbat, Martin
label: Caption

text: Elsasser, and Paul Bonatz. His Swiss student Peter Meyer wrote in the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: that more than two hundred Swiss architects received their training with
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer. Fritz Schumacher, professor of architecture at the Dreseden Tech-
label: Caption

text: nische Hochschule and the keynote speaker at the first Werkbund meeting
label: Paragraph

text: in Munich in 1907, referred to him as the real teacher of a whole generation
label: Paragraph

text: of architects. The historians of the Neues Bauen in the 1920s — Behrendt and
label: Paragraph

text: Gustav Adolf Platz — still spoke of him as a great teacher. In 1932 he was one
label: Paragraph

text: of the few to protest the closing of the Dessau Bauhaus ~ not because he
label: Paragraph

text: was especially sympathetic to its pedagogy but because he believed on prin-
label: Paragraph

text: ciple that an experimental school should be allowed to continue.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout his career Fischer concerned himself with architectural edu-
label: Paragraph

text: cation and was disturbed by its academic trend. He insisted on greater
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on learning through practical experience. One of his moitoes
label: Paragraph

text: reveals his openness to his students’ ideas: “I do not have a fixed conviction.
label: Paragraph

text: I like to hear the opinion of the next generation in order to measure myself
label: Paragraph

text: against it.”* He also encouraged his students to follow their own interests
label: Paragraph

text: and inclinations in order to gain confidence about their work, and he advised
label: Paragraph

text: them to look for examples not in books but in their surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Fig. 1. Theodor Fischer, Bird’s-eye view of a housing project in Gmindersdorf, near
label: Caption

text: Reutlingen, 1903-1915. Munich, Architektursammlung, Technische Universitat Miinchen.
label: Caption

text: Fig. 2. Theodor Fischer, Bird’s-eye view of a housing project in Munich-Laim, 1910-1911.
label: Caption

text: Munich, Architektursammlung, Technische Universitat Miinchen. Photo: Courtesy Dipl.
label: Caption

text: Ing. Klaus Kinold.
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer, whose own architecture was referred to as “South German”
label: Paragraph

text: because of its modest regionalism, was particularly concerned with ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of urbanism and housing. His work has occasionally been associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the artistic planning principles and the emphasis on picturesque urban
label: Paragraph

text: views of Camillo Sitte as reflected in the latter’s Der Stddte-Bau nach seinen
label: Paragraph

text: kiinstlerischen Grundséitzen (City planning according to artistic principles),
label: Paragraph

text: 1889. While Sitte had not dealt with the social and economic issues of plan-
label: Paragraph

text: ning, his approach was based more on developing principles of psychologi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal perception rather than on romantic, aestheticized imagery. Like Sitte,
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer sought a practical aesthetics that was based on empirical studies
label: Paragraph

text: and anthropological constants.**
label: Paragraph

text: Appointed as the director of Munich’s municipal expansion office in
label: Paragraph

text: 1893, Fischer had considerable influence on the development of new con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction. Just as Sitte before him, he was critical of monumental, freestand-
label: Paragraph

text: ing structures and preferred instead building sequences that maintain an
label: Paragraph

text: urban texture and form a continuous enclosure. In addition to private
label: Paragraph

text: commissions he built five schools and three bridges for the municipal gov-
label: Paragraph

text: ernment during his early Munich period. He received a large number of
label: Paragraph

text: commissions for institutional buildings, such as museums and theaters.
label: Paragraph

text: Among his larger projects were the Stadttheater in Heilbronn (t902-1913);
label: Paragraph

text: the Universitat in Jena (1905-1908), for which Taut produced one of the
label: Paragraph

text: renderings; the reinforced concrete Garnisonskirche in Ulm (1908-1910);
label: Paragraph

text: the Hessisches Landesmuseum in Kassel (1907-1913); the Museum in
label: Paragraph

text: Wiesbaden (1911-1920); and the Kunstgebaude in Stuttgart (1909-1913),
label: Paragraph

text: the last probably his most superbly sited public building.
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer completed two houses for Tessenow’s garden city of Hellerau
label: Caption

text: near Dresden (1909-1910) and a school project that remained unexecuted.
label: Paragraph

text: His numerous housing projects include the factory town of Gmindersdorf,
label: Paragraph

text: near Reutlingen (1903-1915; fig. 1), as well as housing in Munich-Laim
label: Paragraph

text: (1910-1911; fig. 2). In his Alte Heide housing estate in Munich (1918-1930),
label: Paragraph

text: executed for workers by a cooperative housing association in response to the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar housing shortages, he turned to the severe scheme of a Zeilenbau
label: Paragraph

text: (housing set in parallel rows) arrangement in order to rationalize as many
label: Paragraph

text: small apartments as possible. It was quite unusual within the context of his
label: Paragraph

text: previous work. His earlier projects influenced the housing of Taut, May,
label: Paragraph

text: and Oud. Alte Heide, on the other hand, prefigures the rigidly rationalized
label: Paragraph

text: Zeilenbau projects of the late 1920s, ostensibly produced to deal with the
label: Paragraph

text: increasing housing shortage and worsening economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the work of Behrens and Josef Hoffmann, Fischer’s approach
label: Paragraph

text: became more conservative stylistically and therefore less influential by the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. Most of his students cannot be called mainstream modernists, but
label: Paragraph

text: several became pivotal figures in the Expressionist Movement in architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture after World War 1, and many turned to social issues of housing. But
label: Paragraph

text: sore, like Elsdsser and Bonatz, remained traditionalists. Bonatz, who had
label: Paragraph

text: become Fischer’s successor at the Stuttgart Technische Hochschule and
label: Paragraph

text: who later became a National Socialist, railed against Fischer as a “wrecker
label: Paragraph

text: of order.” In the end Fischer regretted the increasing stylistic and political
label: Paragraph

text: conservatism of the “Stuttgart School” even though it had originally been
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by his work.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1907 both Behrens and Fischer became founding members of the
label: Paragraph

text: German Werkbund, the association of architects and industrial firms that
label: Paragraph

text: (according to modernist histories) left behind the retrospective ideals of
label: Paragraph

text: the Arts and Crafts Movement and looked instead to progressivist notions
label: Paragraph

text: of art and industry.5? Fischer became the first president of the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: in 1907, and he designed the main hall for the German Werkbund exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion in Cologne in 1914 (fig. 3). Fischer's low-slung, Renaissance-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: structure was flanked on either side by the templelike buildings by
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens and Hoffmann. This group of Werkbund pavilions reveals the
label: Paragraph

text: relative power of these traditionalists vis-a-vis the younger generation of
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Taut, whose Werkbund buildings were assigned compara-
label: Paragraph

text: tively marginal sites. Although Fischer occupied a central position in the
label: Paragraph

text: early Werkbund, he soon withdrew from its ideological struggles and came
label: Paragraph

text: to believe that “this organization for the raising of the production stan-
label: Paragraph

text: dard” should have been dissolved after a few years.%*
label: Paragraph

text: Julius Posener in his text of 1964, Anfange des Funktionalismus (The
label: Paragraph

text: beginnings of functionalism), has already shown that most of the found-
label: Paragraph

text: ing firms — such as the Deutsche Werkstatten fiir Handwerkskunst
label: Paragraph

text: Dresden, Vereinigte Werkstatten fiir Kunst im Handwerk Miinchen, the
label: Caption

text: Wiener Werkstatte, and several publishers — were more closely tied to the
label: Paragraph

text: crafts than to modern industry, even though the intention of some of the
label: Paragraph

text: members was certainly to move in the direction of design for industrial
label: Paragraph

text: production.*® The group had contemplated holding its first meeting in
label: Paragraph

text: Nuremberg, site of Richard Wagner's Meistersinger, in part to emphasize a
label: Paragraph

text: relationship to medieval guilds rather than to industry. In the end the
label: Paragraph

text: first meeting was held in Munich, home of the Werkbund’s first presi-
label: Paragraph

text: dent, Fischer.

label: Caption

text: In addition to architects such as Behrens and Fischer, the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: included among its founding members an architect who all historians will
label: Paragraph

text: agree was conservative both aesthetically and politically, Paul Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg. Hermann Muthesius, who might also be included among the
label: Paragraph

text: conservatives, was instrumental in the creation of the Werkbund as well,
label: Paragraph

text: but for political reasons he had stayed in the background during its first
label: Paragraph

text: meeting, so as not to jeopardize its foundation. As a bureaucrat of the
label: Paragraph

text: Prussian Ministry of Trade in Berlin, Muthesius had criticized the imita-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of styles in art and industry in a speech he made in early 1907; this in
label: Paragraph

text: turn had provoked angry reactions and appeals to Kaiser Wilhelm for his
label: Paragraph

text: dismissal from the Fachverband fiir die wirtschaftlichen Interessen des
label: Title

text: Kunstgewerbes (Trade association to further the economic interests of the
label: Paragraph

text: art industries).°°
label: Paragraph

text: Because of the Werkbund’s extraordinarily varied makeup and the broad
label: Paragraph

text: range of backgrounds among its members, by 1914 (that is, the year of its
label: Paragraph

text: first major exhibition in Cologne), it was already split into hostile factions of
label: Paragraph

text: arts-and-crafis individualists and progressive rationalists, as well as liberal
label: Paragraph

text: and conservative camps. It was referred to at the time as an association of
label: Paragraph

text: the most intimate enemies."?
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the Werkbund’s lack of a clear direction, it became an important
label: Paragraph

text: extra-academic transmitter of architectural ideas through its extensive mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bership, publications, and exhibitions. Stanislaus von Moos has shown that
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier appropriated some of the ideas and images he used in Vers une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture (first published in L’esprit nouveau) from prewar Werkbund pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lications.*? The Werkbund in its very makeup and heterogeneity was a
label: Paragraph

text: reflection of the complex German educational scene in the early twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century. The debate at the Werkbund meeting of 1914 was in fact a political
label: Paragraph

text: one, but it also hinged in part on a misunderstanding of the word Typisierung
label: Paragraph

text: (standardization), prefiguring arguments and differences of opinion in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. Modernism as both practice and ideology was not a uniform concept,
label: Paragraph

text: but it changed in the course of the 1920s and was constantly challenged
label: Paragraph

text: from within and without the movement. The Werkbund, to which Behne
label: Paragraph

text: belonged by 1913, illustrates perfectly the numerous academic and quasi-
label: Paragraph

text: academic prewar institutions that fostered public discussion of the social
label: Paragraph

text: implications of architecture and design.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne, in addition to his association with the Werkbund and his even-
label: Paragraph

text: tual critique of its goals, was a loyal supporter of the Volkshochschule Move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment: a crucial but not well known aspect of nineteenth-century German
label: Paragraph

text: educational reform. The Volkshochschule in Germany evolved in the second
label: Paragraph

text: half of the nineteenth century and was based on Scandinavian models. It did
label: Paragraph

text: not fall within the complex system of professional architectural education
label: Paragraph

text: but added yet another layer to the already pluralistic professional educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tional possibilities. Volkshochschule teaching was like a mixture of American
label: Paragraph

text: adult education and the courses taught to workers and new immigrants
label: Title

text: under Jane Addams at Chicago’s Hull House and many later settlement
label: Caption

text: houses in the early twentieth century. It might further be compared to
label: Paragraph

text: the turn-of-the-century art education movement in Germany, inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Lichtwark, who was appointed the director of the Hamburg Kunst-
label: Paragraph

text: halle in 1886. Lichtwark directed his efforts especially toward the art edu-
label: Paragraph

text: cation of young people. Volkshochschule lectures did not require entrance
label: Paragraph

text: examinations, nor did they lead to diplomas (they were not set up for high
label: Paragraph

text: school equivalency degrees as some such programs are in the United States).
label: Paragraph

text: Courses, lectures, and study trips were meant to further the education of
label: Paragraph

text: the public at large. Behne taught from the beginning until the end of his
label: Paragraph

text: career within this open-ended, unstructured, and completely nonhierarchic
label: Paragraph

text: educational program. Behne’s central role in the Expressionist Arbeitsrat fitr
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst (Work council on the arts) immediately after the war may also explain
label: Paragraph

text: the group’s concern in its manifestos with art education outside of estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished institutions.
label: Paragraph

text: Questions about the place of architecture and design that had arisen
label: Paragraph

text: before the war against the background of a socially complex education sys-
label: Paragraph

text: tem were not resolved after the war. In his well-known opening manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: of 1919 for the Bauhaus (which was initially a state school, then a munici-
label: Paragraph

text: pal school, and finally a private academy), Gropius insisted that only crafts
label: Paragraph

text: can be taught, not art. He used the medieval guilds as his model of instruc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. In 1922-1923 the Bauhaus curriculum began to address the design of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial prototypes, but at the same time it hardly moved beyond a machine
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic; and only from 1928 to 1930, under Hannes Meyer's directorship,
label: Paragraph

text: did Bauhaus instruction concern itself expressly with functionalism. Under
label: Paragraph

text: Mies'’s directorship (1930-1933), the Bauhaus changed focus yet again
label: Paragraph

text: toward straightforward architectural training without regard for the integra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the arts, which had been the mainstay of early Bauhaus teaching.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, however, the Bauhaus is known for its “Bauhaus style” and “Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism.” Gropius later insisted that there was no such thing as a
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus style. He was only partly correct. There were in fact several
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus styles, suggesting an eclectic amalgam of several modernisms.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne's relationship with Gropius and the Bauhaus was an uneasy one. As
label: Paragraph

text: early as 1923 Behne criticized Gropius and the first Bauhaus exhibition for
label: Paragraph

text: its superficial use of several styles at the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: When Gropius had a chance to design a new building for the Bauhaus in
label: Paragraph

text: Dessau, he was asked by his patron, the mayor of that city, to include space
label: Paragraph

text: for the local crafts schoo!. Thus, he could have brought together in a real sense
label: Paragraph

text: traditional crafts training with Bauhaus instruction, but by the mid-1920s
label: Paragraph

text: his pedagogical paradigm had become more technocentric. The two schools
label: Paragraph

text: remained entirely separate entities within the new building, each with its
label: Paragraph

text: own entry. Old hierarchies in the actual relationship between the avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde school and the municipal crafts school were disguised in the modern-
label: Paragraph

text: looking plan of the building: it appears as if it has no center, but Gropius’s
label: Paragraph

text: office was in the bridge that both connected and separated the two schools.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Even before the end of the war, in 1917, Behne wrote a critique of the Werk-
label: Paragraph

text: bund that questioned its nationalist economic goals. He wrote that the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund’s attempt to bring art to bourgeois, commercial, and political
label: Paragraph

text: life would lead only to sentimentality. He considered “artless” utensils far
label: Paragraph

text: preferable to designed ones. He further questioned the “art-into-life” beliefs
label: Paragraph

text: of the Jugendstil and of the Darmstadt Artists’ Colony (which continued to
label: Paragraph

text: form an underpinning of the Werkbund’s principles), as well as the Werk-
label: Paragraph

text: bund’s emphasis on economic competition. The introduction of aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: to the everyday object does not bring about an improvement in quality, he
label: Paragraph

text: went on to argue, but turns it into kitsch. Somewhat perversely he stated
label: Paragraph

text: that he preferred kitsch to the imposition of “art” on ordinary objects. He
label: Paragraph

text: concluded (and here his argument is revealed as proto-Expressionist) that
label: Paragraph

text: art should always remain a separate enterprise.“ His belief suggested the
label: Paragraph

text: bifurcation of art and the everyday, so common in Expressionism and
label: Paragraph

text: probably best known in Gropius's assertion that art cannot be taught.
label: Paragraph

text: in 1920 Behne criticized the Werkbund again in the pages of Sozialistische
label: Paragraph

text: Monatshefte. Once more he complained about its obsession with everything
label: Paragraph

text: artistic, from “artistic norms” to “artistic advertisements.” He hoped that the
label: Paragraph

text: new members on its executive committee (twenty altogether, including
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius, Osthaus, Taut, Bernhard Pankok, César Klein, and Poelzig as direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tor) would bring about a change. He also conceded that the Werkbund was
label: Paragraph

text: correct in rejecting Scheffler’s “Ein Arbeitsprogramm fir den Deutschen
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund” (A working program for the German Werkbund), which had
label: Paragraph

text: insisted on a boycott of all foreign products.%
label: Paragraph

text: After the war Behne became closely associated with the Arbeitsrat fiir
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst, which was founded in 1918, initially under Taut’s leadership, and
label: Paragraph

text: taken over a year later by Gropius. The Arbeitsrat consisted of a group of
label: Paragraph

text: architects, critics, and artists and was modeled on the Arbeiterrate of the
label: Paragraph

text: German Revolution of 1918. It sponsored publications, exhibitions, dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cussions, and circulars that raised questions about art education, public
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and the role of institutions in a postrevolutionary society.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne became the business manager of the Arbeitsrat in 1919 and wrote the
label: Paragraph

text: texts of several of its publications.** Although the Arbeitsrat maintained the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist interest in mysticism, utopianism, and art as a transfiguring
label: Paragraph

text: enterprise, it also became concerned with bringing art to a wider public by
label: Paragraph

text: sponsoring exhibitions in the taverns of Berlin's working quarters. In March
label: Paragraph

text: 1919 the Arbeitsrat followed a suggestion made by Taut and Behne and
label: Paragraph

text: proposed a joint venture with the Werkbund to help with the reconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: of northern France.* This idea for helping war-torn France is a succinct
label: Paragraph

text: example of the groups’ activist pacifism and especially of Taut’s constructive
label: Paragraph

text: utopianism. Behne, however, was not hopeful about the success of this
label: Paragraph

text: effort. He was afraid that if German architects were sent to France, the
label: Paragraph

text: French might wrongly assume that the Germans believed that the French
label: Paragraph

text: did not have qualified architects of their own. The Werkbund, in any case,
label: Paragraph

text: voted the project down.
label: Paragraph

text: By early 1921 when the artists of the Berlin Dada group had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: intensify their critique of Expressionism for its emphasis on individualism
label: Paragraph

text: and for not producing art that appealed to the worker,** the Arbeitsrat had
label: Paragraph

text: already disbanded. As it became clear that the Arbeiisrat’s expectations for
label: Paragraph

text: a new society were far from the political reality, a disillusionment and with-
label: Paragraph

text: drawal from the intense utopianism of the immediate postwar years took
label: Paragraph

text: hold among its former members. As for the Dada effort to create a public
label: Paragraph

text: art, it was no more successful than that of the Expressionists. Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: Dada’s use of collages containing elements taken from the mass media,
label: Paragraph

text: while not necessarily any clearer to the public than the Expressionists’ use of
label: Paragraph

text: folk art or children’s art, proved to be an immensely fruitful artistic direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and prefigured the other “modernisms” of the later 19208. Like the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionists, Dada artists believed that art could be used to revitalize soci-
label: Paragraph

text: ety, a recurrent theme in early twentieth-century German art.
label: Paragraph

text: In an article in Die Weltbiihne in 1926, entitled “An den Verein kom-
label: Paragraph

text: munistischer Kunstmaler” (To the Union of communist painters), Behne
label: Paragraph

text: engaged in a direct confrontation with John Heartfield on the issue of politi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal art. The debate was occasioned by an earlier comment Behne had made
label: Paragraph

text: about an exhibition organized by his friend Otto Nagel, a communist
label: Paragraph

text: painter, in a store in the working-class district in Berlin-Wedding. Heart-
label: Paragraph

text: field, then representing the official position of the kpp, insisted that the
label: Paragraph

text: masses first have to be seized emotionally before art can be discussed.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne, on the other hand, believed that the best art would, in the end, pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duce the best political art. The work on view was intended to show the suf-
label: Paragraph

text: fering of the working class. Behne thought that the working class needed no
label: Paragraph

text: instruction about its suffering and believed that this kind of art was regres-
label: Paragraph

text: sive because it used the same means as bourgeois art. During a lecture
label: Paragraph

text: Behne gave at the exhibition, workers demanded that pictures by Otto Dix
label: Paragraph

text: showing proletarian women be removed. Their realism was found offensive.
label: Paragraph

text: The xpp’s attitude, Behne thought, was not unlike that expressed by the
label: Paragraph

text: National Socialists, and he concluded that if one wants to “seize” the masses,
label: Paragraph

text: one had better understand their psychology. Behne repeated similar ideas in
label: Paragraph

text: an unpublished essay of 1932, “Sozialistische Kunst” (Socialist art).”° He
label: Paragraph

text: praised as successful the paintings of the German section of the Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national Exhibition of Socialist Art in Amsterdam in 1920, as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: Frauen in Not (Women in distress) exhibition, organized by himself and
label: Paragraph

text: Nagel in 1931; the latter was again held in the working-class district of Wed-
label: Paragraph

text: ding.’! The great irony in this debate was that although John Heartfield was
label: Paragraph

text: an outstanding artist, the kpp vacillated in its support of his work.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1921 Behne also became the German correspondent for the English
label: Paragraph

text: periodical The Studio. In 1920 he made a trip to Holland, probably in con-
label: Paragraph

text: nection with the International Exhibition of Socialist Art, where he met Theo
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg, Hendrik Berlage, H. Th. Wijdeveld, and Oud.”? At the same
label: Caption

text: time he was preparing a book on Dutch architecture, Hollandische Baukunst
label: Paragraph

text: in der Gegenwart (Contemporary Dutch architecture), which was published
label: Paragraph

text: in 1922.7? An excerpt from this book was published in De Stijl.
label: Paragraph

text: As the various modern art movements were becoming increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: international in the early 1920s, Behne also made contact with architects
label: Paragraph

text: and artists from other countries. Through his contact with Laszl6 Moholy-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: him Oud received the commission for a Mrs. Kallenbach. Oud came to
label: Paragraph

text: visit Berlin to see the site, but the project fell through in 1922.74 It was
label: Paragraph

text: also Behne who first introduced Moholy-Nagy to Gropius.”> In 1920 Gropius
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: lytize De Stijl.’6 It is revealing that the two figures who in 1922-1923 were
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: toward international Modernism, particularly the incorporation of De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: and Constructivism, in the Bauhaus after 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: During the early 1920s Behne, as well as Taut, was among the founding
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: friends of the new Russia}. Behne thereafter occasionally wrote articles for
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and Moscow, In 1923 he also wrote one of his most insightful reviews of the
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Der moderne Zweckbau
label: Title

text: Despite its title, Der moderne Zweckbau is not a narrow interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism of the sort ascribed to Hannes Meyer by Hitchcock and John-
label: Paragraph

text: son, nor of the sort that postmodernists assume defines Modernism. From
label: Paragraph

text: the outset Behne makes his approach abundantly clear. He defines the
label: Paragraph

text: original need for building traditionally, that is, as a protective device against
label: Paragraph

text: climate, animals, and enemies. The first building, he writes, fulfilled spe-
label: Paragraph

text: cific needs and had a purely functional character. In this sense buildings are
label: Paragraph

text: essentially like tools. But from the beginning of human culture, he contin-
label: Paragraph

text: ues, there has been an urge toward playfulness, coupled with the need to be
label: Paragraph

text: practical. He writes that primitive man was not strictly utilitarian as this
label: Paragraph

text: double urge is verified in tools that are also beautiful and ornamented. The
label: Paragraph

text: house is no exception: a house is as much a toy as a tool. What does change
label: Paragraph

text: over time, in his opinion, is the balance between these two impulses,
label: Paragraph

text: between function and form. In times when formalism has become para-
label: Paragraph

text: mount and tyrannical, it is necessary to stress function. Design, no matter
label: Paragraph

text: what the current emphasis, should always aim for an equilibrium between
label: Paragraph

text: these two competing factors.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus Behne did not insist on the primacy of function as such but consid-
label: Paragraph

text: ered it from a larger historical context that requires periodic adjustment. It
label: Paragraph

text: could be an adjustment that moved toward function or form, but Behne per-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived his own time to be so overwhelmed by formalism that he thought
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis should be placed on functionalism. One might argue at this point
label: Paragraph

text: that Behne was simply employing a larger picture of architecture in order to
label: Paragraph

text: give contemporary functionalism historical legitimacy. His extensive expla-
label: Paragraph

text: nation of the drawbacks of the functionalist position in later segments of the
label: Paragraph

text: book, however, reveals that he was not a mere advocate of functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: His linking the production of tools to the design of architecture is, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, hardly new. With the rise of archaeology and anthropology in the late
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: artifacts became increasingly pronounced. This new concern eventually
label: Paragraph

text: came to include a consideration of crafts in any developmental process.
label: Paragraph

text: Gottfried Semper’s writings, especially his incomplete text on style, are
label: Paragraph

text: probably the best-known instances of such an inclusive approach.** By the
label: Paragraph

text: late nineteenth century Semper's influence could be seen in the art histori-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Although Behne is not an advocate of functionalism, his occasional tan-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
