text: of all requirements of comfort, quiet, and clear design. There is no longer
label: Paragraph

text: any trace of symmetry or an axis, simply walls succinctly marking and
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying the most comfortable traffic patterns for all the rooms. The
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation to living functions goes so far that each piece of furniture
label: Paragraph

text: has its specific place in the floor plan.”® For Behne, Wright's plans “set
label: Paragraph

text: Space in motion as asymmetric as life itself.” The description of Wright's
label: Paragraph

text: interiors and furniture as accommodating living functions may have
label: Paragraph

text: resulted from Behne’s personal sympathy with this arrangement, but it may
label: Paragraph

text: also have been based on his lack of direct experience with Wright's houses.
label: Paragraph

text: Even though their plans are indeed fluid and asymmetrical, there is another
label: Paragraph

text: sort of stasis and control in assigning every piece of furniture and built-in
label: Paragraph

text: elements a fixed place, and this makes Wright’s interiors actually quite
label: Paragraph

text: inflexible. For Behne, as for Le Corbusier, the plan, rather than the eleva-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, has the most important value for contemporary architecture (Hitch-
label: Paragraph

text: cock and Johnson also state that functionalism had its strongest influence
label: Paragraph

text: on the plan).
label: Paragraph

text: Behne then moves on to a discussion of industrial buildings, which he,
label: Paragraph

text: like other modernists, believes are the most impressive in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: He quotes extensively from Henry Ford’s Autobiography, which had just
label: Paragraph

text: appeared as a best-seller in a German translation in 1923. The popularity of
label: Paragraph

text: Ford’s book was but an indication of the cult of Amerikanismus that swept
label: Paragraph

text: Germany in the mid-i920s.* Ford’s description of factory buildings seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to combine the toughness of the demanding industrialist with Taylorism
label: Paragraph

text: and an almost surreal emphasis on the Protestant work ethic and clean-
label: Paragraph

text: liness. It is, in fact, a succinct example of the devolution from the Protestant
label: Paragraph

text: work ethic to capitalism that Weber had described so convincingly in his
label: Paragraph

text: Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism of 1920. Behne quotes Ford thus:
label: Paragraph

text: “Our machines... are scientifically arranged, not only in the sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: operations, but so as to give every man and every machine every square
label: Paragraph

text: inch that he requires and, if possible, not a square inch... more than he
label: Paragraph

text: requires.... The dark corners which invite expectoration are painted white.
label: Paragraph

text: One cannot have morale without cleanliness.”*! Behne also cited Ford’s opin-
label: Paragraph

text: ion on art: “We need artists who master industrial relationships. We need
label: Paragraph

text: masters of industrial methods,” and “We will not put up elaborate buildings
label: Paragraph

text: as monuments to our success. The interest on the investrnent and the cost
label: Paragraph

text: of their upkeep would only serve to add uselessly to the cost of our products
label: Paragraph

text: —so these monuments of success are apt to end as tombs.” Although
label: Paragraph

text: Behne may not have agreed with Ford in general, by using this (and the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Behrens for the akc in particular) as his introduction to the
label: Paragraph

text: design of German factories, he is able to highlight Behrens’s aesthetic inter-
label: Paragraph

text: pretation of form, which Behne earlier had criticized as exhibiting too
label: Paragraph

text: much pathos.®? Henry Ford’s phrase “monuments of success are apt to end
label: Paragraph

text: as tombs” is thus left in place as a signpost to Behne’s interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s turbine factory.
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens, in Behne’s opinion, defines the machine as a pseudoaesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: form. On the other hand, he regarded van de Velde as the first representa-
label: Paragraph

text: tive of a romantic machine cult, in which function is expressed as “dra-
label: Paragraph

text: matic” form. Behne detects van de Velde’s continuing influence with younger
label: Paragraph

text: architects, such as Mendelsohn. In Mendelsohn's work the decorative self-
label: Paragraph

text: satisfaction of Hermann Finsterlin’s organic projects is transformed into an
label: Paragraph

text: engineerlike tension and energy. The attenuated character of Mendelsohn’s
label: Paragraph

text: Einstein Tower borders on anthropomorphism and is “dramatic” in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense of van de Velde’s work. Behne agrees with the Dutch architect J. F.
label: Paragraph

text: Staal that the tower is more memorial than workshop. However, he finds
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s Luckenwalde Hat Factory more sachlich with a purposeful
label: Paragraph

text: organization of its production spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne then further defines his concept of the functional plan, which he
label: Paragraph

text: had touched upon in discussing the work of Wright. He describes orthogo-
label: Paragraph

text: nal space not as a functional form but as a mechanical one. Organic life is
label: Paragraph

text: not determined by the right angle. He gives as examples designs by Haring
label: Paragraph

text: and Hans Scharoun, which on first sight are reminiscent of Finsterlin but
label: Paragraph

text: have none of that painter’s romantic willfulness. He also concedes that only
label: Paragraph

text: an approximate, rather than absolute, adaptation to the natural fluidity of
label: Paragraph

text: movement is possible.
label: Paragraph

text: He makes his expanded notion of functionalism even clearer when he
label: Paragraph

text: goes on to insist that although the functionalist can be extremely practical,
label: Paragraph

text: he is not to be confused with the utilitarian. Whereas the solutions of func-
label: Paragraph

text: tionalists and utilitarians on some occasions may be related, their attitudes
label: Paragraph

text: toward the problem of function are quite different:
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalists are concerned with solving a problem of general significance to
label: Paragraph

text: our culture. The utilitarian only asks: “What is the most practical way for me to
label: Paragraph

text: act in this case?” But the functionalist asks: “How do I act most correctly in
label: Paragraph

text: principle?” Their attitude inclines toward philosophy and has a metaphysical
label: Paragraph

text: basis.... There is no question but that the functionalists, even the most [sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lich] ones, could more readily be classified as romantics than as rationalists.™
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s functionalism at its most extreme would turn the building into a
label: Paragraph

text: pure tool and negate form (play) entirely. Would such an ultimate function-
label: Paragraph

text: alism not lead to a dead end? He responds that the functionalist is right only
label: Paragraph

text: as long as he is concerned with the individual room. Invoking his earlier
label: Paragraph

text: description of the organic functionalist plan, he writes that it is correct that
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal space is not economical, that the curve describes functional
label: Paragraph

text: space with greater precision. But when we group together several such
label: Paragraph

text: “functional” rooms there is a loss of space because of poor tessellation,
label: Paragraph

text: Haring’s device of widening and narrowing corridors to accommodate the
label: Paragraph

text: amount of traffic they bear, for instance, is based on the example of organic
label: Paragraph

text: arteries. A building in this sense, however, is not analogous to a living
label: Paragraph

text: organism that always performs the same function. Haring’s undulating
label: Paragraph

text: corridors assume that they will always carry the same distribution of traffic
label: Paragraph

text: over the life of a building. Behne argues that this type of organic solution,
label: Paragraph

text: which appears functional as a specific response at a certain moment in
label: Paragraph

text: time, may also be too individualistic in a larger built context. Thus, from a
label: Paragraph

text: social point of view, orthogonal space may in fact be more functional
label: Paragraph

text: because it is more neutral when we consider a series of rooms or a group of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings over time. He concludes that the deciding factor must be the gen-
label: Paragraph

text: eral attitude of society.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s argument for a neutral architecture in the public realm resem-
label: Paragraph

text: bles the ideas of Loos. Although Behne mentions Loos only in passing in his
label: Paragraph

text: text, he does list several of his books and essays in a footnote and in his rec-
label: Paragraph

text: ommended bibliography. But in an earlier article in Frihlicht of 1921-1922,
label: Paragraph

text: Behne had specifically pointed to Loos's centrality in the demands for a sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lich architecture.%
label: Paragraph

text: Behne is at the same time always insistent that Sachlichkeit and the ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of a functional architecture must be used to serve people. Staying close
label: Paragraph

text: to postwar Expressionist beliefs, he therefore rejects outright technocentric
label: Paragraph

text: justifications or machine metaphors. He writes that Le Corbusier's concept
label: Paragraph

text: of a “machine for living” is acceptable if we view the machine as a prototype
label: Paragraph

text: for a full-fledged human achievernent. Le Corbusier’s phrase will be misun-
label: Paragraph

text: derstood, according to Behne, if it is applied as a stylistic notion, that is, if it
label: Paragraph

text: is used in the name of a falsely understood Constructivism that assumes
label: Paragraph

text: that buildings and furniture must look smooth, cold, and polished, like
label: Paragraph

text: machines. If it is misconceived, we will only arrive at a new subcategory of
label: Paragraph

text: the Jugendstil, that is, a new taste or a new fashion that is nothing but a new
label: Paragraph

text: pseudo-Constructivist machine formalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne further defines the differences between functionalism, rational-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, and utilitarianism:
label: Paragraph

text: When the functionalist refers to the machine, he sees it as the moving tool, the
label: Paragraph

text: perfect approximation to an organism.
label: Paragraph

text: When the utilitarian refers to the machine, he sees it as an economic prin-
label: Paragraph

text: ciple of saving work, power, and time.
label: Paragraph

text: When the rationalist refers to the machine, he sees it as the representative
label: Paragraph

text: and patron of standardization and typification.**
label: Paragraph

text: His description of the functionalist as someone who interprets the machine
label: Paragraph

text: as an organic model is not much different from Greenough’s mid-nineteenth-
label: Paragraph

text: century functionalism. He does not suggest that functionalism is preferable
label: Paragraph

text: to rationalism but instead describes the pitfalls of both these positions: the
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist, who is concerned first of all with general principles (he places Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier in this category}, must guard against becoming a rigid formalist.
label: Paragraph

text: The functionalist, who is concerned with the specific principle, must be
label: Paragraph

text: careful not to fall into the trap of individually expressed functions.
label: Paragraph

text: In his summary of German architecture in the context of European
label: Paragraph

text: developments, Behne writes that Germany “is somewhat inclined to devote
label: Paragraph

text: itself to an extreme that changes fairly frequently and then gives way to the
label: Paragraph

text: opposite extreme — the consequence of an inner uncertainty."°” He sees Rus-
label: Paragraph

text: sia (the East) and France (the West) as countervailing forces to Germany's
label: Paragraph

text: persistent individualism: “It is a feature common to the East and West that
label: Paragraph

text: ...they proceed from the collective. But the collective is fundamentally dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent here and there: France has a structurally articulated society, Russia is
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by the masses.” Behne, using a social interpretation of interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tionalism, calls for a fusion of these tendencies. He quotes from Heinrich
label: Paragraph

text: Mann to support such a linkage: “We are in the middle and it is our task
label: Paragraph

text: to link East and West; one does not shut off nature. In the future we will be
label: Paragraph

text: the republic in which representation of class and parliamentarianism are
label: Paragraph

text: interlinked.”98
label: Paragraph

text: Behne finds that recent Dutch architecture is also a good model: it exhibits
label: Paragraph

text: a political realism and confidence that save it from the extremes of German
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. He concludes the book with quotations from van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: and Oud and an illustration of Vladimir Tatlin’s Monwment to the Third Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national. In Der moderne Zweckbau Behne does not allude to the conflict in
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch architecture between the Amsterdam School and De Stijl, although
label: Paragraph

text: he had mentioned it in his book Hollandische Baukunst in der Gegenwart, 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: This may have been due to his acquaintance with van Doesburg and Oud, or
label: Paragraph

text: more likely to the fact that by 1923 the Expressionist Amsterdam School had
label: Paragraph

text: waned in importance in the face of van Doesburg’s concerted efforts to prose-
label: Paragraph

text: lytize De Stijl. Behne’s change in emphasis also reflects the shift in Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many from Expressionism to the Neue Sachlichkeit between 1920 and 1923.
label: Paragraph

text: In general, however, his definition of architectural problems as moving
label: Paragraph

text: between form and function, and between East and West in the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: realm, resorts to a dualistic conception. In fact, he recommends a book by
label: Paragraph

text: the German sociologist Alfred Vierkandt, Dualismus im modernen Weltbild
label: Paragraph

text: (Dualism in the modern world picture}, published in 1923. Vierkandt’s
label: Paragraph

text: methodology was phenomenological, not inductive. In this, he followed
label: Paragraph

text: Simmel’s sociology of human interaction. Vierkandt also invoked the treat-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of community and society as irreducible phenomena in the sense of
label: Paragraph

text: Ferdinand Toennies’s Gemeinschaft und Gesellschaft (Community and soci-
label: Paragraph

text: ety), 1887.°° In Behne’s use of this dualism one is also reminded of Wolfflin’s
label: Paragraph

text: reliance on a more formalist dualistic model in his first book, Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: und Barock, 1888. In Der moderne Zweckbau the dualistic paradigm is never
label: Paragraph

text: reduced to a set of rules, however, since Behne investigates the differences
label: Paragraph

text: between form and function only in order to draw them together without
label: Paragraph

text: ever assuming the possiblity of a complete balance.
label: Paragraph

text: Within Behne’s own writings this book was prefigured in his short essay
label: Paragraph

text: “Architekten,” which appeared in Friihlicht, a periodical edited by Taut from
label: Paragraph

text: 1920 to 1922.' Friihlicht was initially an extension of and a voice for the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist Glaserne Kette (Glass chain) group and was first published as
label: Paragraph

text: an appendix to the periodical Stadtbaukunst alter und neuer Zeit (Art of city
label: Caption

text: planning of past and new times). From the fall of 1921 until the summer of
label: Paragraph

text: 1922, it was published as an independent journal in Magdeburg, where Taut
label: Paragraph

text: had been appointed that city’s chief planner. During its Magdeburg phase,
label: Paragraph

text: when Behne’s essay was published, the magazine had shifted away from the
label: Paragraph

text: utopian Expressionism of the postwar years and increasingly covered issues
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture and city planning. The period between 1920 and the stabi-
label: Paragraph

text: lization of the runaway inflation at the end of 1923 (after which architectural
label: Paragraph

text: construction resumed a normal level} is, therefore, a transitional period
label: Paragraph

text: between Expressionism and what is commonly called the Neue Sachlich-
label: Paragraph

text: keit.!°! Friihlicht’s articles during 1922 dealt primarily with urban issues but
label: Paragraph

text: also included an essay by Kurt Schwitters and articles about Russian archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, among them one on Tatlin’s Monument to the Third International.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne's “Architekten” rejects what he calls Expressionism’s “understand-
label: Paragraph

text: able utopianism” and is directed instead toward an internationalism that
label: Paragraph

text: became important after 1919, possibly under the influence of the Third
label: Paragraph

text: (Communist) International or the revival of the Second International by
label: Paragraph

text: more moderate Socialists also in 1919. In this essay he also mentions the
label: Paragraph

text: publication of Mendelsohn’s work in Wendingen and a lecture he gave in
label: Paragraph

text: Holland. Loos, Oud, and Le Corbusier are all cited in terms of their demands
label: Paragraph

text: for a sachlich architecture. He quotes from Le Corbusier in L’esprit nouveau —
label: Paragraph

text: as he was later to do in Der moderne Zweckbau—on the primacy of the plan
label: Paragraph

text: in modern architecture, the banishment of all decoration, as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: idiosyncratic.
label: Paragraph

text: He believes that the new architecture is collective and supraindividual.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne’s anti-individualism also clearly sets this essay apart from his own
label: Paragraph

text: earlier Expressionism. The idea of the “supraindividual” seems to be indebted
label: Paragraph

text: to van Doesburg’s critique of Expressionism and his stress on apparently
label: Paragraph

text: rational forms. What Behne does not address — whereas he exposes many
label: Paragraph

text: forms of pseudofunctionalism and pseudorationalism —is De Stijl’s own
label: Paragraph

text: mystical, Platonic component.'” De Stijl represents an ideology of the objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive that effectively disguises its spiritual and transcendent beliefs.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne ends his essay by pointing to the transition from belief to action.
label: Paragraph

text: He singles out in particular the work of the German cooperative housing
label: Paragraph

text: associations that are helping to introduce rationalization and social concerns
label: Paragraph

text: to the building industry. Quoting Martin Wagner, who headed one of these
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative societies, he details the resistance of the larger building industry
label: Paragraph

text: to change in conventional building methods.’ He asserts that those forms
label: Paragraph

text: belonging to the tradition of handicrafts will change in any case (and here he
label: Paragraph

text: uses an economic argument that had been employed by Loos earlier} because
label: Paragraph

text: they are becoming a luxury. Oud, who had distanced himself from De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: in 1922, became an important architect of social housing in Holland, which
label: Paragraph

text: in turn provided a model for German housing. The cooperative building
label: Paragraph

text: societies in Germany, which were generally set up by unions, benefited in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s from funds that were collected as taxes on speculative building.
label: Paragraph

text: As already noted, in Holldndische Baukunst in der Gegenwart, 1922, Bene
label: Paragraph

text: mentions the tension between the Amsterdam School and De Stij] but writes
label: Paragraph

text: that he prefers the impersonal and sachlich architecture of Rotterdam.'© In
label: Paragraph

text: another essay of 1922, “Kunst, Handwerk, Technik” (Art, craft, technology),
label: Paragraph

text: he makes comparable statements about technology vis-a-vis crafts and sati-
label: Paragraph

text: rizes Gropius’s opening manifesto for the Bauhaus:
label: Paragraph

text: Depersonalization, which is in logical terms a process of objectivization, will
label: Paragraph

text: bring nota creative revival of the crafts and folk art but rather a new and techni-
label: Paragraph

text: cal concept of labor. It is sufficient to glance at the important new European art,
label: Paragraph

text: such as that of Léger, Malevich, Archipenko, Schlemmer, Baumeister, Tatlin,
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian, van Doesburg. Does it still have any inner connections to craft? It is
label: Paragraph

text: antimanual, and instead intellectually constructive and technical. The phase of
label: Paragraph

text: expressionism still cherished the cult of the crafts, but today, when the young
label: Paragraph

text: European art has at last achieved a unison with the time and location of its crea-
label: Paragraph

text: tivity, the infatuation with the crafts (which, as the Dutch architect Oud rightly
label: Paragraph

text: declares, blossoms at times when the delight in singular forms flourishes) is
label: Paragraph

text: finished.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects, sculptors, painters... all of us must return to the crafts??? — No,
label: Paragraph

text: we must move forward toward the demanding service of the intellect!!5

text: As in his Expressionist writings, Behne is openly polemical, but now he
label: Paragraph

text: has become an advocate for De Stijl. In his critique of the Werkbund in 1917
label: Paragraph

text: he had still argued that the aesthetic aura of art kept it from being applied
label: Paragraph

text: meaningfully to the common, everyday object, and in his Expressionist Die
label: Paragraph

text: Wiederkehr der Kunst (The return of art), 1919, he had proclaimed art as
label: Paragraph

text: the only true reality. He now questions the essential unity of the arts, as he
label: Paragraph

text: will later question the idea of Gesamtkumstwerk, which had been an under-
label: Paragraph

text: pinning of design theory from Jugendstil to Expressionism and the early
label: Title

text: Bauhaus. By 1927 in an essay titled “Von der Sachlichkeit,” he refers to the
label: Paragraph

text: ideal of a Gesamtkunstwerk as a fata morgana.'
label: Paragraph

text: In 1924 he wrote a brief article, “Funktion und Form,” in Sozialistische
label: Paragraph

text: Monatshefte. It is basically his introduction to Der moderne Zweckbau and
label: Paragraph

text: uses his toy and tool analogy to form and function.’ He may have pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished this when he realized that Gropius would neither share his illustra-
label: Paragraph

text: tions nor delay the publication of Internationale Architektur.

text: The Terms of the Debate
label: Title

text: Behne's frequent use of Sachlichkeit and Zweck in his book raises questions
label: Paragraph

text: concerning the meaning these terms had for him and whether his usage
label: Paragraph

text: remained the same in the 1920s. Also of interest is the relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: his understanding of these words and that of earlier and later writers. Zweck
label: Paragraph

text: means purpose or function, while Sachlichkeit, although sometimes trans-
label: Paragraph

text: Brerrer
label: Title

text: lated as function, literally means “thingness.” Sachlichkeit is more properly
label: Paragraph

text: translated as “the simple, practical, straightforward solution to a problem,”
label: Paragraph

text: as “matter-of-facmess” and occasionally as “objectivity.” Sachlichkeit simul-
label: Paragraph

text: taneously suggests the world of real objects and that of a conceptual ratio-
label: Paragraph

text: nalism. The philosophical allusions of Sachlichkeit in fact become more
label: Paragraph

text: prevalent in the avant-garde books of the later 19208 and displace to some
label: Paragraph

text: degree the term’s “simple, practical” overtones. Because of its complexity
label: Paragraph

text: and also because of its very particular associations with German culture, we
label: Paragraph

text: have retained the German in this text and the translation. Sometimes Behne
label: Paragraph

text: also uses the terms Funktion and funktionell. On many occasions he uses
label: Paragraph

text: Zweck, Sachlichkeit, and Funktion interchangeably or as a series. But in his
label: Paragraph

text: larger argument, as explained earlier, he draws a clear distinction between
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism, rationalism, and utilitarianism.
label: Paragraph

text: As Harry Mallgrave has shown in his introduction to Otto Wagner’s Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: em Architecture and elsewhere, the architect Richard Streiter used the term
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit as early as 1896 to define realist tendencies that had been a part
label: Paragraph

text: of the German debate for nearly a decade.’ Streiter raised the term in con-
label: Paragraph

text: junction with Zweckméafigkeit and Funktion, establishing a linked meaning
label: Paragraph

text: of these concepts from the beginning. Yet, the precise meaning of Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit was not altogether clearly defined. Streiter, for instance, used the
label: Paragraph

text: word to describe the vernacular architecture of the Bavarian Gabriel von
label: Paragraph

text: Seidl. The following year Lichtwark invoked the term in relation to the
label: Paragraph

text: design of Messel’s Wertheim Department Store in Berlin. This new linguis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic preference within German theory for Sachlichkeit over the older term
label: Paragraph

text: Realismus is made fully transparent in 1899 when Lichtwark, in the course
label: Paragraph

text: of republishing an essay of 1897, changed its title from “Realistische Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tektur” to “Sachliche Baukunst.”!
label: Paragraph

text: Stanford Anderson has examined the use of such concepts in the early
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth century. He writes that Muthesius did not advocate the pure
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit of machines but rather a sachliche Kunst, an approach in which
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics seems to be paramount. Anderson has summed up a turn-of-the-
label: Paragraph

text: century definition as follows:
label: Paragraph

text: It was commonplace to recognize the engineering achievements of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century, from tools or instruments to the great bridges and railroad
label: Title

text: sheds. Whether the critics saw these works as exemplary achievements or,
label: Paragraph

text: resignedly, as the representative objects of a materialist epoch, they could agree
label: Paragraph

text: that such works and the processes that produced them were marked by ratio-
label: Paragraph

text: PHITOGUC ton
label: Title

text: nality, functionalism, and Zweckmafigkeit. Muthesius subsumed such qualities
label: Paragraph

text: under the term “pure” Sachlichkeit....
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit is, then, a convenient umbrella term that invokes simplicity,
label: Paragraph

text: a rational and straightforward attention to needs as well as to materials and
label: Paragraph

text: processes, !1°
label: Title

text: Anderson cautions at the same time that Sachlichkeit cannot be understood
label: Paragraph

text: completely by such a generalization. Variations of meaning existed in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Otto Wagner and Behrens, who — Anderson believes — employed a
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic functionalism.""'
label: Paragraph

text: Behne and the Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Title

text: Since there was already a degree of variation in the way Sachlichkeit was
label: Paragraph

text: used at the turn of the century, we should not expect that the term ever
label: Paragraph

text: assumed a completely uniform connotation. The Neues Bauen in general
label: Paragraph

text: and the references in architectural texts to Sachlichkeit have understandably
label: Paragraph

text: been associated with the Neue Sachlichkeit, a name first popularized by
label: Paragraph

text: Hartlaub in May 1923 when he used it in a circular announcing an exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion at the Mannheim Kunsthalle that took place in 1925. Ina letter to Alfred
label: Caption

text: Barr of July 1929 Hartlaub explained that the term applied to the new real-
label: Paragraph

text: ism with a socialist flavor.'2 In 1923 in a review of the Bauhaus exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: Giedion also mentioned the “neue Gegenstdndlichkeit” (new objectivity) that
label: Paragraph

text: is everywhere in evidence in painting.'? Gegenstand refers to a concrete
label: Paragraph

text: object and is the same as the Russian veshch, which formed part of the Con-
label: Paragraph

text: structivist debate. A Sache, by contrast, is a more general fact or thing with
label: Paragraph

text: abstract connotations.
label: Paragraph

text: The art historian Fritz Schmalenbach, who during the 1930s was at work
label: Paragraph

text: ona book on the Neue Sachlichkeit, noted in an essay of 1940 that Wolfflin
label: Paragraph

text: in his Kunstgeschichtliche Grundbegriffe (Principles of art history) and August
label: Paragraph

text: Grisebach in Die Baukunst im 19. und 20. Jahrhundert, both of 1915, had used
label: Paragraph

text: the term neue Sachlichkeit in passing. Schmalenbach, however, believed that
label: Paragraph

text: Hartlaub’s use of Sachlichkeit should be traced back to its architectural ori-
label: Paragraph

text: gins in the writings of Muthesius, Lichtwark, and Loos.''*
label: Paragraph

text: The use of neve in Neue Sachlichkeit, according to Hartlaub in a letter to
label: Paragraph

text: Schmalenbach, was intended to position the artists in his exhibition against
label: Paragraph

text: the “old bourgeois naturalism of the Diisseldorf Academy.”''® As early as
label: Paragraph

text: 1920 Hartlaub began to criticize Expressionist art for its utopianism and
label: Paragraph

text: argued for a more sachlich Expressionism. In this conjunction of sachlich
label: Paragraph

text: with Expressionistn we find a similarity to Behne’s use of Sachlichkeit, that
label: Paragraph

text: is, at least in the early 19208; the combination was used to suggest a transi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion away from Expressionism without implying a complete rupture with
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism. Even Giedion, who later formed an intense dislike toward
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism, wrote in 1923 that the “neue Gegenstdndlichkeit... has ab-
label: Paragraph

text: sorbed the results of Expressionism.”'!© Dennis Crockett in his disserta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, “Die ‘Neue Sachlichkeit’: Post-Expressionism in Germany, 1919-1925,”
label: Title

text: which contains a more detailed discussion of these issues and a thorough
label: Paragraph

text: overview of the transitional nature of Neue Sachlichkeit in painting, has also
label: Paragraph

text: pointed out that for Hartlaub himself the Neue Sachlichkeit exhibition was
label: Paragraph

text: not about al! of German art at the time — it did not include abstract art, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, nor did it cover, in Hartlaub’s opinion, all of realist art. He never
label: Paragraph

text: regarded it as a counterdevelopment to Expressionism but rather as only one
label: Paragraph

text: tendency in an evolution away from Expressionism. Hartlaub wrote that the
label: Paragraph

text: “new art was already contained in the old” and “retains much of the vision-
label: Paragraph

text: ary quality of the older art.”"? In 1929 Hartlaub noted in his aforemen-
label: Paragraph

text: tioned letter to Barr that
label: Paragraph

text: the expression ought really to apply as a label to the new realism bearing a
label: Paragraph

text: socialist flavour. It was related to the general contemporary feeling in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: of resignation and cynicism after a period of exuberant hopes (which had found
label: Paragraph

text: an outlet in expressionism). Cynicism and resignation are the negative side of
label: Paragraph

text: the Neue Sachlichkeit, the positive side expresses itself in the enthusiasm for the
label: Paragraph

text: immediate reality as a result of a desire to take things entirely objectively on a
label: Paragraph

text: material basis without immediately investing them with ideal implications.!'§
label: Paragraph

text: Schmalenbach, however, in his essay of 1940 did not agree with Hartlaub’s
label: Paragraph

text: specific understanding of the term: “In reality, it was not the ‘objectivity’ of
label: Paragraph

text: the new painting which the term was intended in the first place and above
label: Paragraph

text: all to formulate, but something more universal underlying this objectivity,
label: Paragraph

text: and of which it was the expression, a revolution in the general mental atti-
label: Paragraph

text: tude of the times, a general new Sachlichkeit of thought and feeling.” He also
label: Paragraph

text: wrote that it constituted a “radical rejection of all emotional bias, a deliber-
label: Paragraph

text: ately cultivated unsentimentality."’ Most later historians defined Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in terms of its “sobriety” and “resignation” but usually in oppo-
label: Paragraph

text: sition to Expressionism. Marxist historians in particular saw it as the victory
label: Paragraph

text: of capitalism, Amerikanismus, and Fordism— see, for example, Helmut
label: Paragraph

text: Lethen, Neue Sachlichkeit, 1924-1932, 1970 — or as an instance of a reac-
label: Paragraph

text: tionary culture produced during the period of economic stabilization — as in
label: Paragraph

text: Jost Hermand’s study of Neue Sachlichkeit, 1977.17
label: Caption

text: At any rate, the label from the outset, even Hartlaub’s own early desig-
label: Paragraph

text: nation, was somewhat tenuous because the title of the exhibition itself
label: Paragraph

text: changed as it traveled throughout Germany. Also, Hartlaub’s terminology
label: Paragraph

text: initially competed with Franz Roh’s preferred term Magischer Realismus
label: Paragraph

text: (Magic Realism), which was influenced by Italian metaphysical painting.
label: Paragraph

text: Occasionally historians have categorized two constituent wings of Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit, a left and a right: respectively, those artists who fall under
label: Paragraph

text: Hartlaub’s notion of realism with a socialist flavor, and those who fall under
label: Paragraph

text: Roh’s concept of Magic Realism.!21 In the second half of the decade Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit became a popular label without the distinctions Hartlaub had
label: Paragraph

text: conceived; it was viewed as one example of the several coexisting mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernisms. Schmalenbach clearly preferred to use the term in its later, gener-
label: Paragraph

text: alized, more all-encompassing sense.
label: Paragraph

text: As noted above, in his letter to Alfred Barr of 1929, Hartlaub discussed
label: Paragraph

text: the positive aspect of Neue Sachlichkeit as an enthusiasm for immediate
label: Paragraph

text: reality, whereas its negative side was its cynicism and resignation. Hartlaub
label: Paragraph

text: also explained that “this healthy disillusionment finds its clearest expression
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany in architecture. In the last analysis this battle cry is today much
label: Paragraph

text: misused and it is high time to withdraw it from currency.” Thus Hartlaub,
label: Paragraph

text: who had coined the label in 1923, believed the term to have become mean-
label: Paragraph

text: ingless by 1929. Of course, one does not have to agree with Hartlaub’s
label: Paragraph

text: complete rejection of Neue Sachlichkeit. His complaint about its misuse,
label: Paragraph

text: however, tells us a great deal about its volatility over a brief six-year period.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne, as early as 1926, had referred with a sense of irony to the “gebildete
label: Paragraph

text: Spiessertum’s” (cultured philistines’) enthusiastic embrace of a vulgarized
label: Paragraph

text: version of Neue Sachlichkeit.'?? Most interesting for a discussion of Behne’s
label: Paragraph

text: Der moderne Zweckbau is Hartlaub’s subtle understanding of a multifarious,
label: Paragraph

text: ayered Modernism. To the degree that Hartlaub does not accept Neue Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: ichkeit as a unified, comprehensive term, he seems to be in accord with
label: Paragraph

text: Behne's definition of several directions present in 1923.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more important for understanding the use of Sachlichkeit within
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural debates of the r920s is Schmalenbach’s suggestion that the
label: Paragraph

text: abel Neue Sachlichkeit had its origins in architectural texts written before the
label: Paragraph

text: war. This is supported by Hartlaub’s belief, expressed in 1929, that Neue
label: Paragraph

text: 5I
label: Title

text: Sachlichkeit finds its “clearest expression” in German architecture. If the
label: Paragraph

text: polemics at this stage have become too circular—those in the arts look to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for justification, and those in architecture look to the arts for an
label: Paragraph

text: explanation — we can at least gain some insight from the intensity and back-
label: Paragraph

text: and-forth of definitions that surround the controversies of the Neue Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit. We realize that it was by no means a static concept; it was in fact
label: Paragraph

text: continually redefined. The same is true for Behne’s notion of Sachlichkeit
label: Paragraph

text: and his attitude toward Neue Sachlichkeit: meanings and emphases changed
label: Paragraph

text: in his writings in the course of the 19208.
label: Paragraph

text: In Die Wiederkehr der Kunst, 1919, Behne had elevated the study of folk
label: Paragraph

text: art even above the study of Albrecht Diirer or any high art. He wrote in char-
label: Paragraph

text: acteristic Expressionist fashion that “we must rid ourselves of the rule of
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Folk art dies where technique appears.”'4 He also complained
label: Paragraph

text: about Behrens’s use of Sachlichkeit as if it could be employed as a template.
label: Paragraph

text: In Behne’s essay “Architekten,” 1921-1922, where he frequently refers to
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit, his outright rejection of naturalism still has much in common
label: Paragraph

text: with the Expressionists’ opposition to it, rather than with a resurgent real-
label: Paragraph

text: ism of the Neue Sachlichkeit. He writes that art is a complete product of the
label: Paragraph

text: human spirit and in this sense is antithetical to naturalism. He speaks of a
label: Paragraph

text: tension between the natural and artistic, and he recommends replacing
label: Paragraph

text: naturalism with Oud’s belief in man’s spiritual equality with nature. And
label: Paragraph

text: using one of De Stijl’s curious technospiritual metaphors, Behne concluded
label: Paragraph

text: by exalting the “spiritual freedom of the machine.’ 25
label: Caption

text: When he wrote Der moderne Zweckbau, however, Behne seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been more or less in agreement with Hartlaub, even though he uses the
label: Paragraph

text: term naturalism, rather than realism, as was more common in painting:
label: Paragraph

text: Academic and historical styles have been abandoned and the concept of the
label: Paragraph

text: facade has been disposed of. Yet the “house” is still standing. Success is
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by returning to purpose in an architectural development that has its
label: Paragraph

text: precise counterpart in painting of the period, which likewise disposed of aca-
label: Paragraph

text: demic and historical styles. Its medium is naturalism, which in the develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of painting always allows a new freedom from prejudice, quite analogous
label: Paragraph

text: to the significance that a return to function had for building. “Naturalism in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is functional fitness” (Karl Scheffler: Messel, p. 14).
label: Paragraph

text: In Der moderne Zweckbau Behne did not satisfactorily explain why Zweck,
label: Paragraph

text: Funktion, and Sachlichkeit are often used to form a constellation of words
label: Paragraph

text: that seem to stand for slightly different aspects of Modernism, or why
label: Paragraph

text: Zweckbau is used in the title, and not Funktion or Sachlichkeit. Perhaps these
label: Paragraph

text: were evolving concepts at the time. In his later writings, however, his defi-
label: Paragraph

text: nition becomes clearer and the word Sachlichkeit begins to dominate other
label: Paragraph

text: usages, probably in response to the increasingly widespread use of the term
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Sachlichkett. In one of his books intended for a mass audience, Eine
label: Paragraph

text: Stunde Architektur (One hour of architecture), 1928, he is more explicit re-
label: Paragraph

text: garding the meaning of these terms: “Zweckmédfigkeit is only our minimum
label: Paragraph

text: expectation. We conceive function in a more thoroughgoing way. The archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect must not only fulfill given traditional functions, he must also establish
label: Paragraph

text: new and higher functions. For this reason we shall prefer to speak of Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit.... Therefore, fulfillment of function is for us not an end-in-itself
label: Paragraph

text: but a means to get closer to life.... Reality as a medium of work must be
label: Paragraph

text: conquered.”}?7
label: Paragraph

text: In 1927 Behne expanded his definition of Sachlichkeit in Neues Wohnen —
label: Paragraph

text: Neues Bauen, and Zweck no longer appears as often as it had in 1923. He
label: Paragraph

text: writes that Sachlichkeit does not imply, as most assume, dryness, sobriety, or
label: Paragraph

text: a solution from a purely mathematical point of view. Sachlichkeit simply
label: Paragraph

text: means that the solution is adjusted to the Sache. He then goes on to explain
label: Paragraph

text: what a Sache is: “Each Sache is a nodal point, a crossing point of relations
label: Paragraph

text: between human being and human being.... To work sachlich means there-
label: Paragraph

text: fore to work socially in each discipline. To build sachlich means to build
label: Paragraph

text: socially."8 Behne’s explanation of Sachlichkeit as a primarily social enter-
label: Paragraph

text: prise is similar to Simmel and Weber's notion of social action, and it aligns
label: Paragraph

text: him in fact completely with Hartlaub’s explanation of Neue Sachlichkeit. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, his warning that it has nothing to do with a mathematical
label: Paragraph

text: outlook, as most assume, indicates that by 192'7 a mechanistic and techno-
label: Paragraph

text: centric understanding of the term had probably become prevalent.
label: Paragraph

text: In Newes Wohnen — Neues Bauen Behne further addresses some of the
label: Paragraph

text: social issues that he had begun to explore in his earlier Frithlicht article in
label: Paragraph

text: which he had praised Martin Wagner and the cooperative housing associa-
label: Paragraph

text: tions as a “transition to action” (fig. 8}. He regards the housing shortage as
label: Paragraph

text: the most pressing question in architecture, but goes on to say that housing
label: Paragraph

text: is a political issue from the outset because it cannot be dealt with without
label: Paragraph

text: also confronting the ownership of land (fig. 9). As in his and others’ Expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sionist writings, the idea of the “new man” is still used. This is why he refers
label: Paragraph

text: in the title of the book to dwelling before building.!2° In his Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: writings he had stressed the harmonious, unifying elements of folk art and
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich Zille: “One can kill people as readily with a home as with an From Adolf
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: the Gothic cathedral; the retrospective element of Expressionism here, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, has given way to an international socialism, which had been merely a
label: Paragraph

text: subtext in Expressionism’s anarchist inheritance. This shift in Behne's atti-
label: Paragraph

text: tude completely parallels changes seen in Taut’s work and writings.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne explains in greater detail in Neues Wohnen — Neues Bauen what he
label: Paragraph

text: means by building “socially.” He cites, among other examples such housing
label: Paragraph

text: complexes as the Siedlung Reichsverband fiir Kriegsbeschidigte in Berlin-
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrichsfeld, 1925-1926, for which concrete panels were cast on the site
label: Caption

text: and put in place with the help of cranes on tracks —a method adopted from
label: Paragraph

text: Holland and further refined by Ernst May in Frankfurt. Yet Behne sees stan-
label: Paragraph

text: dardization only as the precondition for social building.”
label: Paragraph

text: In a chapter called “Diktatur oder Sachlichkeit” (Dictatorship or Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit) he writes that Sachlichkeit can help to limit the dictatorship of the
label: Paragraph

text: architect from above and the dictatorship of the tenant from below. He also
label: Paragraph

text: points out that while some housing may took welcoming when new, it will
label: Paragraph

text: look cramped once occupied because the tenants cannot afford new furni-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. Often tenants themselves will add a petit bourgeois feeling to the
label: Paragraph

text: interior by adding valances or antimacassars. But he also sees a tendency in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture toward dictatorship if the building looks too much like
label: Paragraph

text: a prison, and here he cites some of the housing by Oud. Whereas in his ear-
label: Paragraph

text: lier writing he had been apologetic for the plain, apparently “uninteresting”
label: Paragraph

text: look of Oud’s work, he is now more critical, perhaps because Oud had refused
label: Paragraph

text: to provide him with materials for Der moderne Zweckbau. Be that as it may,
label: Paragraph

text: Behne maintains that if ornament is absent, the tenant feels his habitation
label: Paragraph

text: looks like a penal institution and may automatically feel debased to the level
label: Paragraph

text: of the proletariat because ornament is associated with the houses of the rich.
label: Paragraph

text: He concludes that the architect has a tendency toward dictatorship in his
label: Paragraph

text: attitude toward tenants and that tenants are partly right if they expect that
label: Paragraph

text: architects are to serve them. At the same time he suggests that the tenant
label: Paragraph

text: must be educated to become a “ruling type” just like the architect. His call for
label: Paragraph

text: mutual education is rather characteristic of his trust in public education."
label: Paragraph

text: In place of the Gothic cathedral of his Expressionist writings, Behne now
label: Paragraph

text: turns to the image of a medieval knight encased in cumbersome armor as a
label: Paragraph

text: metaphor for the general resistance to the concept of a social Sachlichkeit. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, he uses the walled city and its moat as an analogy for excluding
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in urban issues. He describes the Mietskaserne (literally, rental
label: Paragraph

text: barracks) as the last castle, an example of an isolated, defensive space.132
label: Paragraph

text: Though the normal five-story apartment block with forty to sixty families is
label: Paragraph

text: a proper planning unit, it is in his opinion not an economic unit because
label: Paragraph

text: ownership may change every twenty meters. There may also be a rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: exploitation of the terrain, but this is not a “sachliche, funktional zweckmafige
label: Paragraph

text: solution.” The knight in armor, he writes, has been placed at the disposal of
label: Paragraph

text: high capitalism (figs. 10, 11).133
label: Paragraph

text: In his “Von der Sachlichkeit,” 1927, an introduction to a book on the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Max Taut, Behne writes that a building can have many functiona
label: Paragraph

text: requirements and that Sachlichkeit is really the disciplined thought required
label: Paragraph

text: to weigh them against each other. Here he also launches a very early critique
label: Paragraph

text: of the Zeilenbau, the placement of parallel rows of buildings running north
label: Paragraph

text: and south without regard to the site or street configuration. Behne regards
label: Paragraph

text: the Zeilenbau method as too dogmatic because hygiene has been allowed
label: Paragraph

text: to become the sole determining factor of architecture. This solution, he
label: Paragraph

text: believes, is completely unsachlich and, in the end, formalistic. Behne and
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut among the modernists (fig. 12) —in contrast to Gropius, May,
label: Paragraph

text: and Hannes Meyer—criticized the Zeilenbau, which was used as a plan-
label: Paragraph

text: ning scheme with increasing frequency in the late 1920s. Behne in an essay
label: Paragraph

text: of 1930 would find fault with Gropius’s Dammerstock Siedlung for this
label: Paragraph

text: reason. Martin Wagner, associated with both Behne and Bruno Taut, also
label: Paragraph

text: objected to the Existenzminimum, or minimum housing standard, as defined
label: Paragraph

text: at cIAM 11 in Frankfurt, even though he strongly supported a rationalized
label: Paragraph

text: system of production throughout the 1920s.134
label: Paragraph

text: In Neues Wohnen — Neues Bauen Behne summarizes his argument with
label: Paragraph

text: the statement that the greatest work of art results from the creation of a
label: Paragraph

text: “maximum of human respect for the most.”"5 This assertion in effect
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be simply a slight reformulation of Jeremy Bentham’s eighteenth-
label: Paragraph

text: century utilitarianism, which held that the greatest happiness of the greatest
label: Paragraph

text: number is the self-evident, fundamental principle of morality. Just as utili-
label: Paragraph

text: tarianism later came to be understood as a purely pragmatic, economic con-
label: Paragraph

text: cept — Behne himself uses it in its debased form in Der moderne Zweckbau —
label: Paragraph

text: so the social implication of Behne’s notion of Sachlichkeit, shared by Hart-
label: Paragraph

text: laub’s concept of Neue Sachlichkeit, was made blander and more uniform in
label: Paragraph

text: its popularized form.
label: Paragraph

text: In his Eine Stunde Architektur, 1928, Behne maintained his basically
label: Paragraph

text: antimechanistic notion of Sachlichkeit by writing that fantasy need not be
label: Paragraph

text: left behind.#3* Contrasting the image of the armored knight as a metaphor
label: Paragraph

text: for regression, he introduces the saint as the prophet of Sachlichkeit: “Func-
label: Paragraph

text: tion is the real saint in art history. It helped people to be free.”'4 The cover of

text: Behne’s Blick tiber die Grenze: Baukunst des Auslandes (View across the
label: Caption

text: border: Architecture of foreign countries), published in 1925 in association
label: Paragraph

text: with the Werkbund, contains the same internationalism and many of the
label: Paragraph

text: same ideas expressed the following year in Der moderne Zweckbau. Like his
label: Paragraph

text: “Funktion und Form” article of 1924, this may have been an attempt on his
label: Paragraph

text: part to stake out his position vis-a-vis Gropius’s Internationale Architektur. In
label: Paragraph

text: Blick iiber die Grenze Behne expands upon his critique of German culture as
label: Paragraph

text: moving from one extreme to the other and on its position between East and
label: Paragraph

text: West. He writes that countries with a strong identifiable culture tend to be
label: Paragraph

text: evolutionary and rarely succumb to dictators. He then makes one of his
label: Paragraph

text: politically most insightful statements: “Germany ...lacks a common culture
label: Paragraph

text: and would be easy prey for a dictator, if it did not have a chronic shortage of
label: Paragraph

text: strong authoritarians [Wilensmensch]. No country has a harder time making
label: Paragraph

text: unequivocal decisions. It swings between mistrust and belief, between
label: Paragraph

text: democracy and dictatorship; between union with and isolation from Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: between East and West, between yesterday and tomorrow.”'3* Although criti-
label: Paragraph

text: cal in his assessment, Behne is not sufficiently prescient in believing that
label: Paragraph

text: there is a shortage of authoritarian figures. By 1925, however, he is less san-
label: Paragraph

text: guine than he had been in 1923 when he quoted Heinrich Mann on the need
label: Paragraph

text: for a union between East and West. Still using his dualistic paradigm, he
label: Paragraph

text: describes Russia as Europe’s dynamic pole (speaking about Futurism and
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism) in whose revolutionary setting time becomes defined as
label: Paragraph

text: experience. On the other hand, France to him represents a static pole in
label: Paragraph

text: which time becomes a measure defined by tradition. More interestingly, he
label: Paragraph

text: asks whether politics is not always the determining factor and writes that
label: Paragraph

text: in Italy and Russia political methods have become dictatorial because both
label: Paragraph

text: Bolshevists and Fascists are antidemocratic.
label: Paragraph

text: Just because it was conceived as early as 1923 Der moderne Zweckbau does
label: Paragraph

text: not in every respect prefigure topics that became important in the later
label: Paragraph

text: 19208. After all, much of what is today considered modern architecture had
label: Paragraph

text: not yet been built. Behne is, nevertheless, more comprehensive than Hitch-
label: Paragraph

text: cock and Johnson when it comes, for example, to Russian architecture. He is
label: Paragraph

text: one of the few authors who during this period included the work of a female
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Alexandra Exter’s Isvestia Pavilion (1923). Chronologically, Behne’s
label: Paragraph

text: work might be compared with Mendelsohn’s lecture “Dynamik und Funk-
label: Paragraph

text: tion,” delivered in Amsterdam in 1923, in which Mendelsohn noted:
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas the grasping, pulling, and tearing activities of the machine are purely
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian functions, and function as conceived of in construction demon-
label: Paragraph

text: strates only mathematical inevitability, function in architecture can only mean
label: Paragraph

text: spatial and formal dependence on the givens derived from the program, the
label: Paragraph

text: material and the construction. Therefore it seems impossible to me to some-
label: Paragraph

text: how want to transfer the purposeful function of machines to the space, or the
label: Paragraph

text: technological organization to the organism of architecture.... The machine,
label: Paragraph

text: previously the obedient handyman of deadly exploitation, becomes a construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tive element of a new living organism. ... Thus the machine simultaneously
label: Paragraph

text: becomes a symbol of decay as well as an element of a newly ordered life."
label: Paragraph

text: {In general, Mendelsohn’s concern with expression and the representation of
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic tension clearly differentiates this practicing architect-polemicist
label: Paragraph

text: from the more analytical considerations of Behne, who grouped Mendel-
label: Paragraph

text: sohn with the romantic functionalists.'4°
label: Caption

text: Behne continued to be concerned about the belated publication of Der
label: Paragraph

text: moderne Zweckbau, even after its appearance in 1926. In Neues Wohnen —
label: Paragraph

text: Neues Bauen, 1927, he lists Der moderne Zweckbau both in the text and in the
label: Paragraph

text: bibliography as having been published in 1925, probably a deliberate pre-
label: Paragraph

text: dating that was inadvertently picked up in a bibliography of Behine’s writings
label: Paragraph

text: by the Werkbund Archiv in 1972 and in some other publications." At the
label: Paragraph

text: sare time, Behne, while listing Gropius’s Internationale Architektur in his
label: Paragraph

text: bibliography, does not give it a date. His initial conflict with Gropius over
label: Paragraph

text: the publication of their respective books was clearly not forgotten. Behne
label: Paragraph

text: today, however, has the last word: in the republication of his book in the
label: Paragraph

text: Ullstein Bauwelt Fundamente series in 1964, the date of its conception and
label: Paragraph

text: writing, not of its publication, appears prominently on the cover.
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Behne were often on opposite sides of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: debate in the late 19208, but they also never stopped communicating with
label: Paragraph

text: each other. In October of 1934 Gropius sent a letter to Behne, who by that
label: Paragraph

text: time had been dismissed from his teaching position at the Humboldt-
label: Paragraph

text: Hochschule, as well as at the Stadtische Berliner Volkshochschule (his Sieg
label: Paragraph

text: der Farbe was confiscated as a degenerate text), and was taking a rest cure at
label: Paragraph

text: a sanatorium because he suffered from tuberculosis. Gropius wrote that he
label: Paragraph

text: hoped that Behne was not too depressed and remarked that sometimes such
label: Paragraph

text: an involuntary break is useful in sorting out those events that are truly
label: Paragraph

text: meaningful: “You are not really missing anything here. The conditions are
label: Paragraph

text: so terribly distasteful, because an unparalleled irresolution reigns. Even in
label: Paragraph

text: the camp of those in power opinions swing from one extreme to the other.
label: Paragraph

text: The cultural area, which we think we know especially well, seems gro-
label: Paragraph

text: tesque, and no one, even responsible people with whom I spoke in the min-
label: Paragraph

text: istry of propaganda and in the Reichskulturkammer, know where the trip is
label: Paragraph

text: headed.”!#? Behne’s supposition of 1925 — that Germany would be an easy
label: Paragraph

text: prey for a dictator but lacked authoritarian figures —had turned out to be
label: Paragraph

text: overly optimistic.
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in the Publications of Other Modernists
label: Title

text: None of the later books by Behne’s friends and colleagues carried the
label: Paragraph

text: detailed precision of Der moderne Zweckbau. They tended to rely more on
label: Paragraph

text: their illustrations than had Behne’s book. In Internationale Architektur
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius freely admitted the existence of individual and national characteris-
label: Paragraph

text: tics in current architecture, but despite this he discerned certain unifying
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics, in effect the “international architecture” that had been the
label: Paragraph

text: subject of his Bauhaus exhibition of 1923. He saw the common characteris-
label: Paragraph

text: tics as a manifestation of a shared Gestaltungswille, or creative will. Any
label: Paragraph

text: notion of Sachlichkeit that he perceived as yet another aspect of the new
label: Paragraph

text: mode was subsumed under this idealistic concept of a creative will.!3 In his
label: Paragraph

text: Internationale neue Baukunst, first published in 1927 under the auspices of
label: Paragraph

text: the Werkbund, Hilberseimer finds a unity in contemporary architecture
label: Paragraph

text: much as Gropius had, in the existence of a “creative wil!” rather than a style:
label: Paragraph

text: “The creative will of the architect dominates everything ...[The new archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture is the] expression of spiritual permeation. ... It is not based on a styl-
label: Paragraph

text: istic conception.”'*4 Neither Gropius nor Hilberseimer defines the new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as a style or in mechanistic terms. However, their reliance on the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of a creative will seems to be indebted to Schopenhauer or Riegl’s idea
label: Paragraph

text: of Kunstwollen. Sachlichkeit here seems to be an extension of the creative will
label: Paragraph

text: and not, as in Behne’s explanation, a social issue. Bruno Taut’s definition of
label: Paragraph

text: functional architecture in his book Modern Architecture, 1929, does address
label: Paragraph

text: social and ethical questions, although in a less subtle way than Behne. By
label: Paragraph

text: the 1930s, however, Taut would criticize his own earlier definition as too
label: Paragraph

text: reductive."
label: Paragraph

text: German writers were, of course, not unique in presenting Modernism as
label: Paragraph

text: more than a technocentric polemic. Alberto Sartoris’s Gli elementi dell’archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tettura funzionale (Elements of a functional architecture), first published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1932, defined functional architecture in terms of paired opposites. He saw
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary building characterized by both logic and lyricism, the practi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal and the aesthetic, both matter and spirit.1“¢
label: Caption

text: There were also noteworthy exceptions to this modulated analysis of con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary architecture. Behrendt’s Der Sieg des neuen Baustils, 1927, pub-
label: Caption

text: ished in conjunction with the Stuttgart Werkbund Exhibition, emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: the style of the new architecture: its simple forms, flat planes, and absence
label: Paragraph

text: of ornament. Behrendt regarded this as a proper expression of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary life, which he equated with machines, cars, and airplanes in the
label: Paragraph

text: uninflected manner of early Futurism.” And Giedion, for example, in his
label: Paragraph

text: Bauen in Frankreich, Bauen in Eisen, Bauen in Eisenbeton (Building in France,
label: Caption

text: Building in Iron, Building in Ferroconcrete), 1928, based his methodology
label: Paragraph

text: as he would later in Space, Time, and Architecture) almost entirely on a
label: Paragraph

text: materialistic premise, the development of “new” materials like iron and
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, and the expectation of a yet-to-be-invented, even newer material
label: Paragraph

text: for the twentieth century. In his review of the Bauhaus exhibition of 1923
label: Paragraph

text: he had already set out a similarly deterministic viewpoint. He wrote that
label: Paragraph

text: while each material imposes absolute requirements, the “Stilwille” (style
label: Paragraph

text: will) of our time will select instinctively those materials that are most
label: Paragraph

text: adapted to its psyche, such as glass, concrete, and iron. He adds further that
label: Paragraph

text: above this automatic response to ideal form is the machine.'#* Giedion’s
label: Paragraph

text: curious combination of idealism (Stilwille) with materialism is, of course,
label: Paragraph

text: what prevailed as the standard reading of architectural history into the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: More moderate books published in the second half of the 1920s do not
label: Paragraph

text: differ substantially from those of the avant-garde in a broad and usually non-
label: Paragraph

text: mechanistic interpretation of functionalism. Gustav Platz in Die Baukunst
label: Caption

text: der neuesten Zeit (Architecture of the most recent time), 1927, saw current
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as existing between two poles: between the social, collective
label: Paragraph

text: problems of the period and an unbridled activity of individual impulses.
label: Paragraph

text: Like Behne before him, Platz distinguished between functionalism and util-
label: Paragraph

text: itarianism. Function for Platz could even be a “spiritual, artistic agent.”¥49
label: Paragraph

text: Another one of these moderate books is Berliner Architektur der Nach-
label: Paragraph

text: kriegszeit (Berlin architecture of the postwar period), 1928, edited by E. M.
label: Caption

text: Hajos and L. Zahn. And although its subject was more circumscribed, it had
label: Paragraph

text: a perceptive introductory text by Edwin Redslob. Redslob, an art historian,
label: Paragraph

text: later became (with the Werkbund’s urging) Reichskunstwart, or overseer of
label: Paragraph

text: all federal art projects. He defined modern architecture as follows: “Cre-
label: Paragraph

text: ation, not imitation should be the appropriate expression of our day. For the
label: Paragraph

text: architect this means an end to the repetition of old styles... , but at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time [creation] also mitigates against copying of engineering motifs, some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing the fashion of the day has decreed as a substitute for the despised imi-
label: Paragraph

text: tation of styles.’"*° Not unlike Behne, Redslob regarded both approaches as
label: Paragraph

text: potentially dangerous. He called the imitation of older styles a “decorative
label: Paragraph

text: formalism” produced by the “romanticizers of history”; the copying of engi-
label: Paragraph

text: neering motifs he referred to as “functional formalism” practiced by the
label: Paragraph

text: “romanticizers of technology.”
label: Paragraph

text: What makes it impossible to associate the general notion of Sachlich-
label: Paragraph

text: keit exclusively with Modernism in Germany is that conservatives claimed
label: Paragraph

text: it as well. The most influential among these was undoubtedly Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg, who since the start of the century had produced a series of
label: Paragraph

text: books under the general title Kulturarbeiten (Cultural works). These dealt
label: Paragraph

text: largely with anonymous urban, rural, and garden architecture. Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg’s didactic books were intended for a general public, and they
label: Paragraph

text: were indeed widely read. In addition to texts they also contained pictorial
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts of good and bad architecture, or examples and counterexamples,
label: Paragraph

text: as he called them. In almost all of his comparisons older buildings are seen
label: Paragraph

text: as preferable to more recent ones. Further, his categorical good and bad con-
label: Paragraph

text: trasts made his books a simple, efficient, and popular teaching tool.15!
label: Paragraph

text: In his book Kunst und Rasse (Art and race}, 1928, Schultze-Naumburg
label: Paragraph

text: turned to a racial explanation of visual expression. The best art, he claimed,
label: Paragraph

text: was always produced by pure, unmixed races. He did not insist on the
label: Paragraph

text: supremacy of the Aryan race as some other writers had. Instead, he blamed
label: Paragraph

text: what he regarded as the current low state of the arts on a greater mixture of
label: Paragraph

text: formerly discrete racial types, a racial hodgepodge that he felt was made
label: Paragraph

text: possible by modern technology, especially by the new faster modes of trans-
label: Paragraph

text: portation. Behne castigated Kunst und Rasse in a review of 1929. He wrote
label: Paragraph

text: that aside from its racism, it was patently absurd art history, because
label: Paragraph

text: Schultze-Naumburg assumed a clear analogy between pictorial figural rep-
label: Paragraph

text: resentations and the way the human body actually looks.'5?
label: Paragraph

text: Most interestingly, Schultze-Naumburg criticized modern buildings not
label: Paragraph

text: because they were too abstract nor because they had no ornament, but
label: Paragraph

text: because he linked them with the debased expressions of an industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: society. For this reason he disliked buildings from the late nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century as much as current architecture, He made this point over and over
label: Paragraph

text: in another one of his books of the late 19208, Das Gesicht des deutschen
label: Paragraph

text: Hauses (The face of the German house), 1929, which was really a sequel to
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst und Rasse, but one that dealt exclusively with architecture.’ Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg, for instance, contrasted an old rural town, which for him
label: Paragraph

text: expressed coherence, with modern architecture that displayed what he
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as the incoherence of the machine age. Schultze-Naumburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: good-and-bad juxtapositions do not have quite the moralizing conviction of
label: Paragraph

text: Augustus Welby Pugin’s Contrasts of 1836. Nevertheless, as in Pugin, there
label: Paragraph

text: is in all of Schultze-Naumburg’s writings a high degree of nostalgia for a
label: Paragraph

text: less confusing past. Both men reacted against industrialization and urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ization. While the Industrial Revolution had occurred in England over a
label: Paragraph

text: long period of time, in Germany it was telescoped into a few decades of
label: Paragraph

text: the late nineteenth century, producing disturbingly rapid social changes
label: Paragraph

text: that, in the words of the historian Golo Mann, “could be compared to an
label: Paragraph

text: explosion.”!54 What Schultze-Naumburg seemed to look for in preindustrial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was the security of calm simplicity and also, surprisingly, Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit. In the preface to Das Gesicht des deutschen Hauses he wrote that his
label: Paragraph

text: object with the earlier Kulturarbeiten had been to call attention to the then
label: Paragraph

text: little-noticed, simple, bourgeois architecture before 1800. In fact, Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg’s selections are almost analogous to those of Pau] Mebes in his
label: Paragraph

text: influential Um 1800 (Around 1800) of 1908.'* It represents, in effect, a Bie-
label: Paragraph

text: dermeier revival of sorts with parallel implications of a withdrawal from the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary world and its social upheavals into a more comfortable realm
label: Paragraph

text: of older conventions.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Schultze-Naumburg objected to the Werkbund’s Weissenhof
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung — illustrated by him without proper identification (ail counter-
label: Paragraph

text: examples are condemned in his books to eternal anonymity) —he rejected
label: Paragraph

text: not its severity, abstract quality, or even modern “style.” What he disliked
label: Paragraph

text: was the absence of pitched roofs. While Schultze-Naumburg had been an
label: Paragraph

text: early member of the Werkbund, by 1925 he had distanced himself from its
label: Paragraph

text: activities. For Schultze-Naumburg the pitched roof was the primordial
label: Paragraph

text: element of the house. He wrote that to omit it would be like having a face
label: Paragraph

text: without a nose (a rather awkward physiognomic analogy). His general objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, symptomatic of contemporary conservative reactions to Modernism, is
label: Paragraph

text: part and parcel of a racial theory of physiognomic expression. But at the
label: Paragraph

text: game time he also couched his critique in a rational argument. He wrote
label: Paragraph

text: that the flat roof may be quite suitable for a Mediterranean setting, where it
label: Paragraph

text: can be regarded as an indigenous ethnic expression, but he found it totally
label: Paragraph

text: inappropriate in the North, where it lacks tradition and is impractical. He
label: Paragraph

text: complained that the new architecture pretends to be sachlich but is nothing
label: Paragraph

text: of the sort. Although his argument was rife with inconsistencies, he and
label: Paragraph

text: other traditionalists claimed Sachlichkeit for themselves. Possibly because of
label: Paragraph

text: the inflammatory quality of Schultze-Naumburg’s writings, the flat roof of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture became a major issue of the architectural debate in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany."** This was surely an instance of the negative side of the intense
label: Paragraph

text: architectural polemics in Germany in the early twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: To summarize attitudes in Germany in the 1920s, questions of function-
label: Paragraph

text: alism ranged from the nuanced discussion of Behne, to the more simplis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic idealizing interpretation of Gropius and Hilberseimer, to the reductive
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian-pragmatic explanation of Schultze-Naumburg, in whose writing
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit is a cover for ethnic appropriateness. The functionalism ascribed
label: Paragraph

text: by Hitchcock and Johnson to Hannes Meyer was hardly symptomatic of the
label: Paragraph

text: whole conceptual development and complexities of this issue in German
label: Paragraph

text: theory.
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s Modern Architecture, used by David Watkin to criticize the mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernist notion of functionalism, contains the following passage: “The out-
label: Paragraph

text: ward characteristics of the new construction — flat roofs, huge sheets of
label: Paragraph

text: glass... horizontal ribbon windows with pillars...were finally reduced to
label: Paragraph

text: the level of a kind of sport, as has happened and is still happening to the
label: Paragraph

text: admirable ancient styles.... In the same way, the ‘modern’ style has been
label: Paragraph

text: imitating itself” (figs, 14a, b).!5” Thus three years before Hitchcock and John-
label: Paragraph

text: son elevated conternporary aesthetic tendencies to stylistic principles, Taut
label: Paragraph

text: had already satirized them as fashionable clichés. Like Taut, his friend
label: Paragraph

text: Behne had demonstrated even earlier that the definition of a modern style
label: Paragraph

text: should not be of central concern. By investigating the ideologies behind the
label: Paragraph

text: various approaches to functionalism in the early 1920s, he uncovered at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time the eclecticism and pluralism of early Modernism.

text: In the last few decades of European architecture, Baroque design has
label: Paragraph

text: congealed into an arid academicism. Among the very rare buildings of char-
label: Paragraph

text: acter are Franz Schwechten’s Stettin and Anhalt railroad stations in Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: The plan was dominated by facades overloaded with decorative motifs,
label: Paragraph

text: Heidelberg castles with a “composition” irrelevant to their functional
label: Paragraph

text: requirements. The most grotesque example: Ihne’s Staatsbibliothek in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin, a concrete building that needs an artifical, complicated iron frame
label: Paragraph

text: to support its sandstone Baroque facade, like a mask; or, by the same
label: Paragraph

text: (hne, the Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum, in whose plan the flight of stairs in the
label: Paragraph

text: vestibule could be moved from one side to the other without having the
label: Paragraph

text: slightest effect on the architecture of the building as a whole.®
label: Paragraph

text: At almost the same time a determined opposition, associated with the
label: Paragraph

text: names of H. P. Berlage, Alfred Messel, and Otto Wagner, was successfully
label: Paragraph

text: asserting itself in Holland, Germany, and Austria.” Buildings by these lead-
label: Paragraph

text: ing architects, which became benchmarks, are the Amsterdam Stock
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange, the Wertheim Department Store in Berlin, and the buildings for
label: Paragraph

text: the Vienna Stadtbahn. Work on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange started in
label: Paragraph

text: 1897, the first phase of the Wertheim Building on LeipzigerstraBe was com-
label: Paragraph

text: pleted in 1898, and the Vienna Stadtbahn dates from 1894 to 1897. The
label: Paragraph

text: casino in Saint-Malo by the brothers Auguste and Gustave Perret, with a
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete vault that is very bold for its period, dates from the
label: Paragraph

text: same time (1899/1900). But, as was so often also the case with the Perret
label: Paragraph

text: brothers’ later buildings, the architecture remained untouched by the con-
label: Paragraph

text: structional innovations.§

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
