text: lf we look more closely, we ought to recognize that the Wertheim
label: Paragraph

text: Building—to put it paradoxically —is more revolutionary than its architect,
label: Paragraph

text: yet not as revolutionary as it seems. This is because, despite the energy
label: Paragraph

text: and lack of prejudice with which it fulfills its purpose, it is not absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: sachiich. It quickly turned out to be a mistake to try to see the Wertheim
label: Paragraph

text: Building as the prototypical department store; for apart from Sehring’s Tietz
label: Paragraph

text: store at the other end of LeipzigerstraBe, which adopted the glass surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: on an even bigger scale, subsequent developments did not follow Messel’s
label: Paragraph

text: exampie.!6 Furthermore, outside Germany it had absolutely no effect at all.
label: Paragraph

text: But even in Germany, beginning with Olbrich's Tietz store in Dusseldorf,
label: Paragraph

text: we soon see walls once again gaining mass, the system of piers receding,
label: Paragraph

text: and horizontals again reappearing, so that by the time we get to Emil
label: Paragraph

text: Schaudt’s Kaufhaus des Westens in Charlottenburg, there is nothing at all
label: Paragraph

text: left of Messel’s system. No doubt this development was affected by building
label: Paragraph

text: codes that for fire protection required a solid wall at least one meter high
label: Paragraph

text: between every two floors; thus, horizontal articulation was arrested, but the
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate reasons went deeper than this.
label: Paragraph

text: Messel’s facade seemed highly structural in its intention, but in the
label: Paragraph

text: shadow of the roof and behind the capital-like ornamental headwork the
label: Paragraph

text: piers are without much ado transformed into a harmless wall, thus revealing
label: Paragraph

text: that the grandiloquent profile is merely decorative. The connection between
label: Paragraph

text: roof and wall is very superficial, and the roof is a feeble, spaceless stopgap.
label: Paragraph

text: In a competition design of 1910 for an extension to Messel’s building,
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut underlined Messel’s principle with greater purity: his smooth
label: Paragraph

text: piers are arched above to form the wall supporting the roof.!” In his design
label: Paragraph

text: for a Mittag department store in Magdeburg (1913), the same architect
label: Paragraph

text: carried Messel’s idea of verticality to its logical constructional solution by
label: Paragraph

text: supporting the roof from above with concrete piers using a system of arches.
label: Paragraph

text: Messel’s piers were not really the strong element that they first
label: Paragraph

text: appeared but rather the weak element of his building. They were a conse-
label: Paragraph

text: quence of the unclear thinking that led Messel to stack five ground floors on
label: Paragraph

text: top of one another. The idea of increasing display space fivefold is—looking
label: Paragraph

text: at the matter rationally—a mistake, as only the ground-floor windows are
label: Paragraph

text: actually display windows. The upper rows of windows have little or no signifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cance for advertising purposes; in fact, displays were very quickly removed
label: Paragraph

text: from them and replaced with screenlike stands. Thus one did not even
label: Paragraph

text: take full advantage of an additional light source. This is why we said that
label: Paragraph

text: Messel’s idea, directed solely at light and display space, was not entirely
label: Paragraph

text: sachlich. It led him to stack five floors of display windows atop one another,
label: Paragraph

text: and this in turn led to a verticality that brought piers into being as a stop-
label: Paragraph

text: gap measure; basically the piers are nothing more than the additive lifting
label: Paragraph

text: above the street level, a fivefold raising of the street elevation — making
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s remark that modern German architecture is frequently an
label: Paragraph

text: “elevator-shaft architecture” absolutely accurate in the case of the Wertheim
label: Paragraph

text: Buiiding.18 And it is also because of the internal inconsistency of these
label: Paragraph

text: apparently so grandiloquent piers that the roof sits on them as it does:
label: Paragraph

text: unrelated, thin, and random, like a makeshift roof. (Anyone wishing to
label: Paragraph

text: adopt the terminology of Leo Frobenius in Das unbekannte Afrika could see
label: Paragraph

text: verticalism as a continuing effect of Ethiopian-tellurian pile-frame architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and horizontalism as a persisting element of Hamitic-chthonic building.
label: Paragraph

text: It is incidentally also remarkable that Frobenius describes Hamitic social
label: Paragraph

text: structure as horizonta! layering [castes] and Ethiopian social structure as
label: Paragraph

text: vertical layering [clans].)}!9

text: There is thus a great deal to criticize in this building of 1898, which
label: Paragraph

text: when it was expanded, probably contrary to Messel's original conception,
label: Paragraph

text: acquired multiple axes. And yet at the time it was of the greatest signifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cance, although this was probably more psychological than strictly tectonic.
label: Paragraph

text: The department store as a type did not develop in this direction, not in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, indeed not even in Berlin, and Messel himself recognized why in
label: Paragraph

text: the way he terminated the building facing Leipzigerplatz. Here, warmly
label: Paragraph

text: applauded by cultured people, he adopted an ecclesiastical note with a
label: Paragraph

text: strong Gothic element, which led a Berlin critic to remark that the opening
label: Paragraph

text: of a new department store in the Lustgarten (Raschdorff's cathedral) cain-
label: Paragraph

text: cided with the consecration of a new cathedral on Leipzigerplatz.2
label: Caption

text: The ecclesiastical note had already been struck in the first building
label: Paragraph

text: phase with the system of tall monumental piers. When foreshortened, they
label: Paragraph

text: closed to form a solemn church wall. It rather gave the impression of a
label: Paragraph

text: gigantic Gothic church converted into a store by installing intermediate ceil-
label: Paragraph

text: ings and glass paneling. In the first building phase this tendency may have
label: Paragraph

text: derived from an inner uncertainty, but in the section facing the square it
label: Paragraph

text: became a conscious game with Gothicizing style elements.
label: Paragraph

text: Allin all this building, apparently designed more radically in pursuit of
label: Paragraph

text: purpose than any other of its period, is a very artificial construction, which
label: Paragraph

text: is probably clearest when one compares it with, for instance, the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of the Louvre Department Store in Paris.
label: Caption

text: It cannot be said, however, that this establishes a new type —if there
label: Paragraph

text: really is such a thing! The fact that a department store has become much
label: Paragraph

text: larger has not changed the basis for the French architect. He thinks per-
label: Paragraph

text: haps more conservatively but also genuinely more sachlich. He places large
label: Paragraph

text: display windows where they are appropriate and have a purpose: on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground floor. On the upper stories there are many windows arranged in
label: Paragraph

text: regularly ordered rows. One story is placed above another: not as a repeated
label: Paragraph

text: ground floor but as second, third, fourth, and fifth floor, i.e., with conscious
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on the horizontal, corresponding to reality. Finally the vaulted roof
label: Paragraph

text: with its many skylights and chimneys makes the whole thing look like a
label: Paragraph

text: warehouse, a gigantic storehouse accommodating a large number of things
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time. in brief, the modern department store ultimately finds a
label: Paragraph

text: mode of expression here where it was not being sought, an expression more
label: Paragraph

text: genuine and purer than in Messel’s work —simply because the tendency to
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose stylization is absent, a tendency that inclined excessively toward
label: Paragraph

text: art and thus led to a falsely ecclesiastical character, isolating the building
label: Paragraph

text: fram its neighbors, although its purpose is not particularly different from
label: Paragraph

text: theirs. The Louvre Department Store remains entirely a part of the street,
label: Paragraph

text: and precisely this is part of its truth. As the department store was built quite
label: Paragraph

text: specifically in, on, and for the street, it is not allowed to be the most alien,
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuous, and isolated building along the entire street, which was the
label: Paragraph

text: case with Messel’s store along LeipzigerstraBe.
label: Paragraph

text: Messel’s pointed, one-sided emphasis on a single function —display—
label: Paragraph

text: made him untrue to the whole; the building lacked integration.
label: Paragraph

text: If we nevertheless assign Messel’s building such an important place, it is
label: Paragraph

text: because it had enormous psychological impact. He gave others the courage
label: Paragraph

text: to break away from conventional schemes, to dare to create new types—
label: Paragraph

text: even though his own attempt was far less happy and far less sachlich than it
label: Paragraph

text: first appeared.

text: The modern country-house plan was also developed in the mid-1890s by the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago architect Frank Lloyd Wright, Sullivan's student.2! Conventional ter-
label: Caption

text: minology would not place the country house in the category of functional
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, but the sensibility articulated in Wright's new floor plans is extra-
label: Paragraph

text: ordinarily important as it is characterized by the liberation of the plan from
label: Paragraph

text: formalist rigidity by returning to the functional element. This development
label: Paragraph

text: begins somewhere between the plans for the Winslow House in River Forest
label: Caption

text: (1893) and the Heller House in Chicago (1896) and reaches its peak in the
label: Paragraph

text: plan for the Coonley House in Riverside (1908). Here Wright has given up
label: Paragraph

text: fitting the rooms together in an ornamental scheme in favor of “free balanc-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in space” (Herre), based on the most careful inclusion of all require-
label: Paragraph

text: ments of comfort, quiet, and clear design.?? There is no longer any trace of
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry or axis, simply walls succinctly marking and accompanying the
label: Paragraph

text: most comfortable traffic patterns for all the rooms. The accommodation to
label: Paragraph

text: living functions goes so far that each piece of furniture has its specific place
label: Paragraph

text: in the floor plan. This plan “unfolds.” The house is not complicated by stairs
label: Paragraph

text: ascending to the upstairs —a rudiment of medieval castle and masonry wall
label: Caption

text: architecture. The plot of land has space enough to allow the building and
label: Paragraph

text: almost all its rooms to develop directly at ground level.
label: Paragraph

text: In Wright’s plans the rooms are not inserted next to one another but set
label: Paragraph

text: in motion —as asymmetrically as life itself, strangely enough. Influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: the Japanese, Wright already started building unusually flat roofs, mostly
label: Paragraph

text: with wide overhangs. This means suppressing the picturesque and stressing
label: Paragraph

text: constructional and cubic elements. It is logical that a house organized as
label: Paragraph

text: reely balanced spaces should reject the roof as a hat that unites every-
label: Paragraph

text: thing. Even the roof changes from a “motif” into a “function.”
label: Paragraph

text: Wright's influence on European architecture was significant: in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: (Peter Behrens, Gropius, Mendelsohn, Mies van der Rohe); in Holland (Oud
label: Paragraph

text: b. 1890], Jan Wils, van t'Hoff, Greve); in Switzerland (Le Corbusier); in
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakia (Obrtel, Krejcar, Tyl, Cerny, Vigek, Fragner, Feuerstein) — at
label: Paragraph

text: irst probably affecting the elevation more than the plan, which has only
label: Paragraph

text: recently come to be fully understood.??
label: Paragraph

text: Compositionally, Wright's country houses are of the greatest significance
label: Paragraph

text: because they consistently emphasize the horizontal. Their high-tension,
label: Paragraph

text: nervy force, always contrasting ingeniously with concise verticals, actually
label: Paragraph

text: makes the houses look as though they are a component of the street,
label: Paragraph

text: although in their very idiosyncratic interpenetration of public and private
label: Paragraph

text: space they almost never open to the roadside. Eschewing all ornament,
label: Paragraph

text: which to our taste often plays a surprising role in the interior (recently
label: Paragraph

text: increasing also on the exterior), he achieves the aesthetic composition of
label: Paragraph

text: the house from the basic elements of accelerated horizontal movement,
label: Paragraph

text: subtly and strikingly stopped verticals, and textured walis that never appear
label: Paragraph

text: as supporting but always as supported parts. All visible parts are com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletely conveyed as function: the precise relationship of open and closed
label: Paragraph

text: areas produces the “building”
label: Paragraph

text: Every attentive observer senses the close connection with machine aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetics, completely new in the history of architecture. In an essay for the
label: Paragraph

text: New York Architectural Record in 1908, Wright says:
label: Paragraph

text: The machine cannot be removed from the world, it is here to stay. It is the fore-
label: Paragraph

text: runner of the democracy that is the final goal of our hopes and dreams.
label: Paragraph

text: There is no more important work before the architect now than to use this
label: Paragraph

text: modern tool to the greatest possible extent. But what does he do instead? He
label: Paragraph

text: abuses this tool in reproducing forms born of other times, under distant skies,
label: Paragraph

text: forms that today seem boring because one cannot avoid them anywhere; all
label: Paragraph

text: of this happens with the help of the machine, whase main task it is to destroy
label: Paragraph

text: just these forms.?4

text: Berlage, Otto Wagner, and Alfred Messel (the latter with the reservations
label: Paragraph

text: mentioned above) had successfully championed the cause of Sachlichkeit.
label: Paragraph

text: But their Sachlichkeit was restricted primarily to resisting and avoiding
label: Paragraph

text: Unsachlichkeit. Common sense, a feeling for cleanliness and its practice
label: Paragraph

text: found acceptance, and fear of purpose ceased. But they still failed to
label: Paragraph

text: address the task directly enough. They remained house builders. It may be
label: Paragraph

text: that their commissions (stock exchange, office building, etc.) had some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing to do with this. At any rate, they did not approach the plan in a new
label: Paragraph

text: way. Even Otto Wagner expressly stresses the importance of symmetry
label: Paragraph

text: in the plan: “A simple, clear plan in most cases requires the symmetry of
label: Paragraph

text: the work. In a symmetrical arrangement there is some measure of self-
label: Paragraph

text: containment, completeness, balance; an impossibility of enlargement; even
label: Paragraph

text: self-assurance. Gravity and dignity, the constant companions of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ure, also demand symmetry.”25
label: Caption

text: Wright provided the first real breakthrough. Through a positive Sach-
label: Paragraph

text: lichkeit, he developed the country-house plan as something new and directly
label: Paragraph

text: based on life, by returning to the most elementary functions of the inhabi-
label: Paragraph

text: ants. This was the decisive turn from formal restraint to a commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: ife itself—in the confidence that a form appropriate to a healthy and
label: Paragraph

text: orderly life will of necessity be beautiful — space newly conquered by purpose
label: Title

text: and function.
label: Paragraph

text: This attitude, when applied to the great tasks typical of the times, could
label: Paragraph

text: ead to a new architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: And to an increasing extent in the first decade of the century, factory
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and industrial problems represented just such tasks.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: facade has been disposed of. Yet the “house” is still standing. Success is
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by returning to purpose in an architectural development that has
label: Paragraph

text: its precise counterpart in painting of the period, which likewise disposed
label: Paragraph

text: of academic and historical styles. Its medium is naturalism, which in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of painting always allows a new freedom from prejudice, quite
label: Paragraph

text: analogous to the significance that a return to function had for building.

text: The distinguishing feature of these American buildings (without exception
label: Paragraph

text: the work of engineers, not architects) is their complete absence of compul-
label: Paragraph

text: sive ideas about form, their quite unprejudiced design, and their spatial
label: Paragraph

text: ealization of production and working processes. Take the grain silos for
label: Paragraph

text: he Washbury-Crosby Company in Buffalo: a group of vertical tubes of dif-
label: Paragraph

text: erent heights and widths, with bracing quite openly revealed —no hint of
label: Paragraph

text: adding, balancing, or refinement. Note also the contrast of angular eleva-
label: Paragraph

text: tor sections and connecting tracks extending horizontally, an absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical and irregular plant that for this reason is so convincingly a
label: Paragraph

text: legitimate and thrilling example of functional or dynamic building. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: building that seizes upon tensions arising from the production process, and
label: Paragraph

text: in working with them it actively articulates space without inhibitions or sup-
label: Paragraph

text: pressions. It is completely analogous to the approach of Wright, who has
label: Paragraph

text: had no industrial commissions himself with the exception of the Larkin
label: Paragraph

text: Building in Buffalo. (The film studios [sic] in Olive Hill, California, also can-
label: Paragraph

text: not be classified as such.) In order to show the strong effect of these works
label: Paragraph

text: In the motherland of industry, in America, large industrial plants have been built
label: Paragraph

text: whose unknown majesty excels even that of our best German buildings in this
label: Paragraph

text: genre. The grain silos in Canada and South America, the coal stores for the great
label: Paragraph

text: railway lines, and the ultramodern factories for North American industries are
label: Paragraph

text: almost comparable to the buildings of ancient Egypt in their monumental power.
label: Paragraph

text: Their architectural features have such assurance that the purpose of the complex
label: Paragraph

text: is made unambiguously comprehensible to the observer with convincing force. The
label: Paragraph

text: self-evident truth of these buildings does not come from their materia! superiority
label: Paragraph

text: in extent and scale—this is certainly not where the reason for their monumental
label: Paragraph

text: effect is to be found. It is much more that those who built them seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: retained a natural sense for large-scale, concise forms in a way that is indepen-
label: Paragraph

text: dent, healthy, and pure. There is a valuable lesson in all this for us. We should
label: Paragraph

text: once and for all cease paying attention to historical yearnings and other misgivings
label: Paragraph

text: of an intellectual nature, which are crippling modern European artistic creativity
label: Paragraph

text: and obstructing artistic naiveté.°6

text: Henry Ford’s remarks on the subject of factory building are very typical:
label: Paragraph

text: One point that is absolutely essential to high capacity, as well as to humane pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction, is a clean, well-lighted and well-ventilated factory. Our machines are
label: Paragraph

text: placed very close together — every foot of floor space in the factory carries, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, the same overhead charge. The consumer must pay the extra overhead
label: Paragraph

text: and the extra transportation involved in having machines even six inches farther
label: Paragraph

text: apart than they have to be.... This brings our machines closer together than
label: Paragraph

text: in probably any other factory in the world. To a stranger they may seem piled
label: Paragraph

text: right on top of one another, but they are scientifically arranged, not only in the
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of operations but so as to give every man and every machine every
label: Paragraph

text: square inch that he requires and, if possible, not a square inch, and certainly not
label: Paragraph

text: a square foot, more than he requires... When we put up the older buildings, we
label: Paragraph

text: did not understand so much about ventilation as we do today. In all the later build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings, the supporting columns are made hollow and through them the bad air is
label: Paragraph

text: pumped out and the good air introduced. A nearly even temperature is kept every-
label: Paragraph

text: where the year round and, during daylight, there is nowhere the necessity for arti-
label: Paragraph

text: ficial light.... The dark corners which invite expectoration are painted white. One
label: Paragraph

text: cannot have morale without cleanliness, We tolerate makeshift cleanliness no more
label: Paragraph

text: than makeshift methods” (p. 113 ff.).29
label: Caption

text: Ford writes about his hospital: “Because of the arrangements it is easily
label: Paragraph

text: possible for a nurse to care for seven patients who are not desperately ill. In
label: Paragraph

text: the ordinary hospital the nurses must make many useless steps. More of
label: Paragraph

text: their time is spent running around than caring for the patient. This hospital
label: Paragraph

text: is designed to save steps” (p. 55).3°
label: Paragraph

text: It will not take us too far away from the point at hand to quote the
label: Paragraph

text: longer passage in which Ford formulates his attitude toward art:
label: Paragraph

text: We seemingly limit the creative functions to productions that may be hung on
label: Paragraph

text: walls, or heard in concert halls, or otherwise displayed where idle and fastidious
label: Paragraph

text: people gather to admire each other's culture. Bui if a man wants a field for vital
label: Paragraph

text: creative work, let him come where he is dealing with higher laws than those of
label: Paragraph

text: sound, or line, or colour; let him come where he may deal with the laws of person-
label: Paragraph

text: ality. We need artists who master industrial relationships. We need masters of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial methods. We need those who can mould the shapeless mass in political,
label: Paragraph

text: social, industrial, and moral respects into a sound and shapely whole. We have
label: Paragraph

text: limited the creative faculty much too much and have misused it for too trivia! ends.
label: Paragraph

text: We need men who can create the working design for all that is right and good and
label: Paragraph

text: desirable (p. 104).3!
label: Paragraph

text: Ford is also being entirely consistent with this when he says:
label: Paragraph

text: We will not put up elaborate buildings as monuments to aur success. The interest
label: Paragraph

text: on the investment and the cost of their upkeep would only serve to add uselessly
label: Paragraph

text: to the cost of our products —so these monuments of success are apt to end as
label: Paragraph

text: tombs. A great administration buiiding may sometimes be necessary, although it
label: Paragraph

text: arouses my suspicion that perhaps there is too much administration. We have
label: Paragraph

text: never found a need for elaborate administration and would prefer to be advertised
label: Paragraph

text: by our product, rather than where we make our product (p. 173).32

text: The first European to solve industrial tasks in the grand style was Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens (b. 1868), whom Emil Rathenau called to be artistic adviser to the
label: Paragraph

text: AEG in 1907.33
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens started his career as a painter in Munich, moved on to
label: Paragraph

text: decorative and applied artwork at an early stage, and risked the leap to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Darmstadt in 1901. The house in Darmstadt was followed
label: Paragraph

text: by the Dusseldorf exhibition garden (1904), the Oldenburg exhibition pavil-
label: Paragraph

text: ions (1905), a private house in Saarbriicken, some rooms for the Dresden
label: Paragraph

text: Applied Arts exhibition [Kunstgewerbeausstellung] (1906), and the crema-
label: Paragraph

text: torium in Hagen, Westphalia (1907), all works then outstanding for their
label: Paragraph

text: stereometric simplicity and conscious return to clear, cubic proportions. It
label: Paragraph

text: is certainly not yet possible to talk about a real creation of space; there
label: Paragraph

text: is more reduction than production, more graphics than architecture. But
label: Paragraph

text: there was an unmistakable hint of a modern attitude in the work, a pleasure
label: Paragraph

text: in concise, precise, and technical form—elements that make Rathenau’s
label: Paragraph

text: choice seem the happiest that could have been made at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: What had been happening in German industrial architecture until then?
label: Paragraph

text: Factories were thrown up here, as everywhere, in the rawest and cheap-
label: Paragraph

text: est way with, in fact, insulting contempt. Not even a minimum of design
label: Paragraph

text: consideration was wasted on them, and if occasionally a bit of Gothic trac-
label: Paragraph

text: ery or a Renaissance gable was added, the effect was all the more artificial.
label: Paragraph

text: Factories with dark courtyards, narrow passages, blind windows, and low,
label: Paragraph

text: dark rooms, more like prisons than places for productive work, repellent,
label: Paragraph

text: stifling, joyless hammer mills mirrored perfectly the ever more terrible back
label: Paragraph

text: premises of the urban tenements in which the majority of toilers in the fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory had to live. No one has drawn the horrific misery of these buildings —
label: Paragraph

text: with their hordes of subtenants, lodgers, transients, and illicit stills — more
label: Paragraph

text: accurately and movingly than Heinrich Zille.44
label: Paragraph

text: This hopeless brutality, this contemptuous negation of all design con-
label: Paragraph

text: sciousness was highly fitting for a period dominated by middle-class culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Art was Raphael and Hans Makart, and what did a factory have to do with
label: Paragraph

text: Raphael and Hans Makart?!35

text: Peter Behrens’s early work for the AEG was on a small scale. Arc lamps,
label: Paragraph

text: fans, electrical cooking and heating equipment were designed simply,
label: Paragraph

text: clearly, and logically, entirely without ornament. Behrens’s great gift for
label: Paragraph

text: creating new aesthetic values with the object itself was already beginning to
label: Paragraph

text: show, and this was probably the first time in our age that things emerged
label: Paragraph

text: that were typical rather than individual in form. Great emphasis was placed
label: Paragraph

text: upon precise proportions and appropriate handling of materials. These
label: Paragraph

text: works aroused general interest, for instance, at the Berlin shipbuilding exhi-
label: Paragraph

text: bition of 1908. They were an early attempt at a clear and pure form for
label: Paragraph

text: our times.
label: Paragraph

text: The AEG’s most important buildings are the HuttenstraGe Turbine Factory
label: Paragraph

text: (1909), high-voltage factory (1910), small-motor factory (1911), assembly
label: Paragraph

text: plant (1912)—all at Humboldt-Hain. Later came buildings for other indus-
label: Paragraph

text: rial concerns, such as the administration building for the Mannesmann
label: Paragraph

text: Factory in Dusseldorf (1911/1912), the Frankfurt Gasworks (1911/1912), the
label: Paragraph

text: NAG [Nationale Automobil-Gesellschaft] Factory in Berlin-Oberschéneweide
label: Paragraph

text: (1920), and more recently, the administration building for the Héchst Dye
label: Paragraph

text: Factory.
label: Paragraph

text: We should not underestimate the contribution made by Peter Behrens in
label: Paragraph

text: recognizing the historical meaning of the task that fell to him. Early on he
label: Paragraph

text: correctly sensed that here was a jab to do that had to be fundamental for
label: Paragraph

text: he formation of a style for our times. From the start, Behrens had no
label: Paragraph

text: doubts that he had to adapt his work to typical solutions. The poorly imi-
label: Paragraph

text: tated, dissipated, ornate Baroque motifs jumbled together to suffocate,
label: Paragraph

text: inhibit, and dislocate any life there might have been in the original architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural rhythms were, with a new pride, replaced by the beauty of the pure
label: Paragraph

text: surface, of taut smoothness, of precise and concise outline, and of exact
label: Paragraph

text: edges — fitting things for an age in which the machine had started to orga-
label: Paragraph

text: nize a fundamentally new working process. Wright was unmistakably a
label: Paragraph

text: model for all this.

text: Here are some striking passages from an essay by Peter Behrens for the
label: Paragraph

text: AEG (Plakat, June 1920):
label: Paragraph

text: In questions of form for all industrial plants it is always a matter of creating char-
label: Paragraph

text: acter from the very nature of the things to be designed, to discover the type, just
label: Paragraph

text: as all past art is seen today to reveal sublime greatness by being typical of the
label: Paragraph

text: respective condition of the times. This means no less than that one must address
label: Paragraph

text: all the artistic and technical conditions that a plant imposes, support them,
label: Paragraph

text: indeed elevate them to a fundamental principle and let this principle become a
label: Paragraph

text: visible expression.
label: Paragraph

text: This applies first to the placement of the building. It has to follow the scale of
label: Paragraph

text: the production process. The location of railroad tracks is crucial to the siting of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. Staggering the buildings allows for the proper entry of rail tracks
label: Paragraph

text: through the gates of the factory buildings. At the same time spacious storage
label: Paragraph

text: yards should be provided, and this touches upon a city planning principle of great
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic significance. It is precisely this staggering of buildings, necessary in
label: Paragraph

text: Practical terms, that will give the plant an effective silhouette; and the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: layout of the yards fulfills a demand by a past master of city planning, Camillo
label: Paragraph

text: Sitte, who described a square enclosed by buildings as one of the most necessary
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of architectural effects.
label: Paragraph

text: Whenever the opportunity arises to compare plants designed from such a
label: Paragraph

text: purely practical point of view with others based on random factors or built in
label: Paragraph

text: stages, one is astonished to see how such different impressions can be created
label: Paragraph

text: with the same expenditure of construction and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: But the same is also true of a factory’s interior layout. The spatial arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: grows out of the organization of the production process. Clear layout, ease of
label: Paragraph

text: interchange and forward movement of products, and unhampered mobility of tools,
label: Paragraph

text: machines, or trucks require open, uncluttered, well-lit halls. Workplaces should be
label: Paragraph

text: as well lit and spacious as possible. It is therefore recommended that staircases
label: Paragraph

text: and elevators be moved to the exterior; this will at the same time make the archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural effect more impressive, producing a long sequence of work spaces inside
label: Paragraph

text: and on the outside rows of windows picturesquely enlivened by protruding stair-
label: Paragraph

text: wells and elevator shafts towering above the roof. Since light is a prerequisite for
label: Paragraph

text: good work, factory buildings should have large window openings; they should
label: Paragraph

text: dominate, control the surface of the building, and lend support in their effect as
label: Paragraph

text: windows. For this reason they should not seem like large holes in the wall but
label: Paragraph

text: appear flush with the outer wall, giving the exterior a friendly appearance .3¢

text: If we compare Peter Behrens’s achievements with American examples,
label: Paragraph

text: the crucial difference is that Behrens is still intent on stylization, on artistic
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation through form, whereas the Americans present the object com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletely bare. There is no doubt that Behrens was extraordinarily refreshed,
label: Paragraph

text: broadened, and strengthened in his forms by an unprejudiced accommeda-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to the living process of industry, but in the end his behavior was not
label: Paragraph

text: altogether without prejudice. He abandoned a number of conventions, gave
label: Paragraph

text: up a great deal of rigidity and tradition, but he did not unquestioningly
label: Paragraph

text: devote himself to the purpose, to function. Many concepts persisted for him,
label: Paragraph

text: even the concept of a “house.” And it is just this clinging to this notion of a
label: Paragraph

text: house that compels him to stylize. For how could the small-motor factory on
label: Paragraph

text: VoltastraBe express itself as such —and Peter Behrens cared for “expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion” — other than by applied forms (in this case strongly stressed piers) if
label: Paragraph

text: the basic layout of the plan is not fully and unconditionally committed to the
label: Paragraph

text: thing, and then of course it is no longer a “house.”
label: Paragraph

text: A duality still remains in the case of Behrens: a good fulfillment of pur-
label: Paragraph

text: pose and its integration into a normal body — wall, roof, window, etc. But
label: Paragraph

text: because he wanted to destroy the normal house for the sake of a greater
label: Paragraph

text: and more powerful concept, Peter Behrens’s pathos was born, which unfor-
label: Paragraph

text: tunately found many imitators. For example, Stoffregen’s Delmenhorst
label: Paragraph

text: Factory showed an inclination toward the vertical, perhaps still under the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Messel.#8
label: Caption

text: It is now very interesting to see that the earliest of Behrens’s AEG build.
label: Paragraph

text: ings makes the greatest and freest break with the conventional house
label: Paragraph

text: type, and that his last industrial buildings (Oberschéneweide) are classical.
label: Paragraph

text: There seems to be a certain analogy with Messel's development.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Turbine Hall in HuttenstraBe there suddenly emerged an indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial building that was a new type, a new life: no longer a “house,” no longer
label: Paragraph

text: a shed, no longer convention, and no longer a cross between various his-
label: Paragraph

text: torical types. For the first time in this country, industry built a workspace
label: Paragraph

text: solely according to work requirements, not as a trivial stopgap but with self-
label: Paragraph

text: confident strength, using the new materials iron, concrete, and glass. The
label: Paragraph

text: new feature of this building was the stronger unification of a more massive
label: Paragraph

text: body. The body built here to house the working process was an indivisible,
label: Paragraph

text: unbroken whole: from socle to ridgeline its mass is informed with a will and
label: Paragraph

text: a life; it stands like an improbable giant amid the childishly stuccoed tene-
label: Paragraph

text: ment facades of the area. Decoration, ornament, and form were swep
label: Paragraph

text: away. The building was itself form, it needed no forms. The shaping force
label: Paragraph

text: was directed away from an obsolete concern with facade ballast and toward
label: Paragraph

text: the body, toward fulfilling purpose, and toward exploiting the new materi-
label: Paragraph

text: als. They had of course been used before (Perret), but with a few exceptions
label: Paragraph

text: their style-forming possibilities had never been recognized.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to this, in the Frankfurt Gasworks we find once again the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: abstract forms (“sphere, cone, and cylinder”). In the NAG buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: Oberschéneweide we definitely find the emphasis on classical form, the
label: Paragraph

text: neutralization of function and purpose behind impenetrable calm, here con-
label: Paragraph

text: sistently also forgoing any expression. The house reasserts itself.

text: We could establish a parallel between the Turbine Hall and the Wertheim
label: Paragraph

text: It is clear from the Alfeld factory how much Gropius's study of American
label: Paragraph

text: There is a sense of distant refinement, even caution, that detracts from

label: Paragraph

text: ity. This simplicity could almost be called complicated. It vacillates between
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: From this point forward, two trends in contemporary European architecture
label: Paragraph

text: diverge fairly sharply; they can be called eastern and western. Both are
label: Paragraph

text: aligned with Sachlichkeit, both like to make reference to machines, both
label: Paragraph

text: want an expression of our time and our region, but they arrive at very difter-
label: Paragraph

text: ent results. Otherwise, the boundaries are entirely fluid.
label: Paragraph

text: At the time of the Russian Revolution artists in Russia and Germany
label: Paragraph

text: began to negate the concept of “art.” They no longer wanted to be producers
label: Paragraph

text: of luxuries, they wanted to fulfill a necessary function in the life process of
label: Paragraph

text: society. They rejected decoration entirely, commited themselves to construc:
label: Paragraph

text: tion and artistic production, and opposed any sort of aesthetics or concern
label: Paragraph

text: with form.
label: Paragraph

text: The Russian engineer Lapshin declared, for example: “There is no archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture as such and no separate architecture as such, there is only uniform,
label: Paragraph

text: strictly scientific design.... So-called artistic matters still dominate build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing.’55 We have to come closer to the style of our times. (The demand for an
label: Paragraph

text: independent “style for our times” is found already with Schinkel and has
label: Paragraph

text: been echoed by every architect since. Schinkel says: “Why should we always
label: Paragraph

text: want to build in the style of another period? Why should we not try to invent
label: Paragraph

text: a style of our own!?") No artists were summoned to build the Palace of
label: Paragraph

text: Labor in Moscow, but factory managers with great technical expertise were
label: Paragraph

text: brought in. Lapshin is against treating building from an aesthetic point of
label: Paragraph

text: view and suggests that it should become part of engineering.
label: Paragraph

text: The surest guiding principle to absolutely sachlich, necessary, extra-aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: design seemed to be adaptation to technical and economic functions, which
label: Paragraph

text: with consistent work must in fact lead to the dissolution of the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: form. Thus building would unconditionally become a tool.
label: Paragraph

text: Strict suitability to functions —what could the building gain by that?
label: Paragraph

text: When the parts of a building are arranged according to a sense of their
label: Paragraph

text: use, when aesthetic space becomes living space —and this is the kind of
label: Paragraph

text: order we call dynamic—the building throws off the fetters of the old, fos-
label: Paragraph

text: silized, static order, axes, symmetry, etc., and achieves a new starting point.
label: Paragraph

text: A cramped, material, stable equilibrium (symmetry) gives way to a new,
label: Paragraph

text: boider equilibrium, delicately balanced in broad tensions (polarity) that cor-
label: Paragraph

text: respond better to our essence, and with this comes a form that is entirely
label: Paragraph

text: new and alive, free from constraints and stabilization.
label: Paragraph

text: And then, through this suitability to function, a building achieves a much
label: Paragraph

text: broader and better inner unity: it becomes more organic by abandoning the
label: Paragraph

text: old conventions and formalisms of representation, which inhibit the materi-
label: Paragraph

text: alization of necessary form.
label: Paragraph

text: It is therefore no wonder that architects tried to exploit the possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: of functionalism to the full. Building presumes the optimum functional
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the proposed living space; architecture is no more than a
label: Paragraph

text: fixed and visible structure of the final organization of every movement,
label: Paragraph

text: every occupation, every purpose and use of the building.” It is no small
label: Paragraph

text: architectural achievement if all the paths through a building relate to each
label: Paragraph

text: other clearly and coherently, absolutely free and open to every possible
label: Paragraph

text: combination, and not just in a mechanical sense — “twelve doors in a long
label: Paragraph

text: corridor” — but with the aim of achieving the finest and most ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: organization and best possible construction. The architect can only grasp
label: Paragraph

text: and carry out his truly artistic work, that is, the creative work, when he
label: Paragraph

text: addresses questions of his client’s attitude to life, way of living, business
label: Paragraph

text: methods — something that of course he can only do with him, not without
label: Paragraph

text: him or against him. For this reason “being a client” is not just buying a
label: Paragraph

text: piece of land, some bricks, and an architect. The client must be an activity,
label: Paragraph

text: whose taking possession of the acquired space is so definite, clear, rich,
label: Paragraph

text: and organic that it can be transformed into the relationships of masonry
label: Paragraph

text: walls, indeed relationships governed not by convention or mere custom but
label: Paragraph

text: by necessity and a living sense.

text: The rectangular room and the straight line are not functional but
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The flow of organic life knows no right angles and no straight lines.
label: Paragraph

text: And as the functionalist always appeals to the flow of organic life as the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: posed by architects (meaning the competition entries for the Palace of Labor in
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow) will never contain within its gates the tens and hundreds of thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: people who will surge to the Pantheon of the Revolution on November 7th, Its
label: Paragraph

text: walls will stand too silent and immobile, its doors will be too narrow, its acoustics
label: Paragraph

text: will be unsuited for the hundred thousand voices of the jubilant people.
label: Paragraph

text: Why not erect a gigantic building on an enormous, rotating steel foundation
label: Paragraph

text: with removable glass and aluminium wails? Such a palace would be capable of
label: Paragraph

text: guiding the masses of people from roam to room, opening itself up to magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: halls. bringing masses of listeners closer to speakers from its various platforms.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of elevators, continuously rotating spiral ladders will carry people up to
label: Paragraph

text: the roof. Why should one not, for example, set up some rooms, classes, laborato-
label: Paragraph

text: ries, and operation theaters that can in turn swing around to the south and the
label: Paragraph

text: sun, and in the evening flood the street with light to be exploited for general artis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic and educational purposes?
label: Title

text: We must proceed to a new building material: steel, ferroconcrete, and espe-
label: Paragraph

text: cially Duralumin, glass, and asbestos. We now see a shift to these materials
label: Paragraph

text: across the whole cultural front. It would be a disgrace to build a palace in the
label: Paragraph

text: heart of Red Moscow, in the residence of the Federation of the Soviet Union,
label: Paragraph

text: whose physiognomy is directed to the past when it should serve the revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: present.
label: Paragraph

text: Aside from dynamic building, a number of other constructional problems must
label: Paragraph

text: be solved in the Palace of Labor. Acoustics in the large halls must be strengthened
label: Paragraph

text: with an electric membrane. Walls must literally speak with the assistance of radio
label: Paragraph

text: telephones. Walls, ceilings, and vestibule must become translucent when neces.
label: Paragraph

text: sary. The radio must be exploited to full advantage. Radio waves must beam
label: Paragraph

text: through glass corridars to activate electric motors driving ventilation and various
label: Paragraph

text: other devices like cooking facilities, for example. The roof must be suitable for
label: Paragraph

text: walking in the open air, cinema, lighting effects, sport, etc.#8
label: Caption

text: (In discussing this, Akseiski said the following: “Things like this have not
label: Paragraph

text: even been carried out in America. Without disputing the possibility in princi-
label: Paragraph

text: ple of such a building in the future, it must be said that it would be ridicu-
label: Paragraph

text: fous to try to build it at the moment.”) It is impossible to think of a sharper
label: Paragraph

text: contrast with the Russian Selinski than the Frenchman Albert Gleizes, who
label: Paragraph

text: in his Vom Kubismus writes in the chapter on “Dynamism”: “A flower is
label: Paragraph

text: immobile. It can be moved by outside forces — otherwise it remains static.
label: Paragraph

text: A painting is a silent and immobile manifestation. To speak of dynamism
label: Paragraph

text: when dealing with a painting is to give words a meaning that they do not
label: Paragraph

text: havet” (p. 30).8%
label: Paragraph

text: The element of movement is shared by German functionalism and
label: Paragraph

text: Russian dynamism (biomechanics). (Italian Futurist architecture falls into
label: Paragraph

text: the same category, although after the early death of Sant’Elia, killed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1916, Virgilio Marchi is probably the only one who still represents it. Marchi
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes and underlines individualistic, dramatic, dynamic, and lyrical
label: Paragraph

text: elements. “Every architect has his own rhythm and his own law that does
label: Paragraph

text: not coincide with that of anyone else.”)9° In Germany one is dealing with
label: Paragraph

text: movement as an expression of individual life, with a pseudo-organic, plastic
label: Paragraph

text: movement working from within, whereas in Russia one is dealing with instal-
label: Paragraph

text: ation, montage, and constructing frameworks. Working from the outside
label: Paragraph

text: ike this, almost without a plan, produces ingenious constructivist works that
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately remain always studio objects, as is seen, for instance in
label: Paragraph

text: Ladovski’s class at VAHUTEMAS Moscow,?!
label: Paragraph

text: Plasticity and construction are both features of architecture, but they
label: Paragraph

text: are not themselves architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: tis a feature common to the East and West that, in contrast to individualist
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, they proceed from the collective. But the collective is fundamen-
label: Paragraph

text: ally different here and there: France has a structurally articulated society;
label: Paragraph

text: Russia is dominated by the masses. A by-product of this is that the plan is
label: Paragraph

text: a major feature in the West but is addressed strikingly tittle in the East.
label: Paragraph

text: here and in fascist Italy the plan is replaced by direct tension of masses.
label: Paragraph

text: The problem is to fuse the two tendencies, statics and dynamics. In an
label: Paragraph

text: excellent essay “Der jung-europaische Staat” (Vossische Zeitung, 25 Sep-
label: Caption

text: tember 1923), Willy Hellpach recommended this task to Germany in terms
label: Paragraph

text: of national law: “The remedy is not to compe! emergent professional forces
label: Paragraph

text: to submit to the imaginary authority of Platonic powers again — in history
label: Paragraph

text: attempts of that kind always end with the complete ruin of the formal
label: Paragraph

text: powers — but to create a new state with real authority by taking those forces
label: Paragraph

text: that have emerged as a result of powerful spiritual processes of radical
label: Paragraph

text: change in the nation and integrating them into the state as legal, synarchic
label: Paragraph

text: forces, thus putting an end to their unlawful, anarchic effects."92
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich Mann takes a similar line: “We are in the middie and it is our
label: Paragraph

text: task to link East and West; one does not shut off nature. In the future we
label: Paragraph

text: will be the republic in which representation of class and parliamentarianism
label: Paragraph

text: are interlinked.”93
label: Paragraph

text: The exclusive fulfillment of purpose, the one-sided focus on function
label: Paragraph

text: makes the individual building dynamic and qualifies it. It becomes one “con-
label: Paragraph

text: sequence” within a flow of biological dependencies, with a logical inclination
label: Paragraph

text: to include the temporal factor. One-sided focus on form gives statics the
label: Paragraph

text: rigidity of a general, abstract “law.” Interpenetration of the two elements
label: Paragraph

text: makes the building a living, concrete “form” [Gestalt].
label: Paragraph

text: “Consequence” — “law” — “form.” This is the terminology of Paul Tillich’s
label: Paragraph

text: Das System der Wissenschaften nach Gegenstanden und Methoden. The law:
label: Paragraph

text: “The thinking person can look away from individual being to create some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing general, comprehensive” (physics). Consequence: “The individual
label: Paragraph

text: becomes part of a (temporal) context” (history). Form: "The individual being
label: Paragraph

text: becomes a general being. Form is actually the concrete, the real being”
label: Paragraph

text: (technology) (Christian Herrmann in a critique of Tillich, Sozialistische
label: Paragraph

text: Monatshefte, 1923, p. 569).*
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Vierkandt in his Dualismus im modernen Weltbild [Dualism in the
label: Paragraph

text: modern world image] seems close to such a view.% Christian Herrmann
label: Paragraph

text: sums up his doctrine like this:
label: Paragraph

text: In this sense every culture is by its very nature built upon a dualism of principles.
label: Paragraph

text: For on the one hand culture represents the epitome of the meaning of life, derived
label: Paragraph

text: from life, or aimed at its preservation and furtherance, in brief, things that exist
label: Paragraph

text: from the point of view of utility; but on the other hand, such things have their own
label: Paragraph

text: intrinsic value that opposes the content as that which formed it. Tension of this
label: Paragraph

text: kind can be seen in all spheres of culture. This dysfunction between a utilitarian
label: Paragraph

text: and a defined content and it’s pure formation as form can be seen everywhere, in
label: Paragraph

text: law, art, religion, economics, society, science, and technology. In the life of the
label: Paragraph

text: soul we find the same dualistic confrontation, for on the one hand it is a process
label: Paragraph

text: entirely determined by biology, on the other hand, however, it leads to patterns
label: Paragraph

text: with their own meaning and value. Spiritual acts are causally determined by their
label: Paragraph

text: antecedents, but they are also determined by the meaning that they serve. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: human beings are closely attached to two worlds: the world of biological necessity,
label: Paragraph

text: a dark natural bedrock full of hardships, and a spiritual world with specific content
label: Paragraph

text: and substance. (Sozialistische Monatshefte, 1923, p. 287).**
label: Paragraph

text: If we return to the building, we can say that its concrete form is a com-
label: Paragraph

text: promise between individual (function) and society (form). In its pure devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment this compromise is inhibited by “expression” and “soul.” Its pure

label: Paragraph

text: less” [gestaltios].9° Closed form in the sense of a “figure” is today no longer
label: Paragraph

text: a satisfying element in art, either in architecture or in other fields. A drive
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The younger generation of German architects insists on strict Sachlich-
label: Paragraph

text: le
label: Title

text: keit. Mies van der Rohe explains: “We reject all aesthetic speculation, all
label: Paragraph

text: doctrine, and all formalism. Let form be shaped by the nature of the task,
label: Paragraph

text: using the means of our time. That is our work.” Otto Wagner had already
label: Paragraph

text: insisted on the same thing in a very similar formulation.
label: Paragraph

text: The necessary and only sound approach is to reject aesthetic specula-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, formalism, and doctrine, but it seerns to us quite a frequent error to
label: Paragraph

text: make this rejection from an anti-aesthetic point of view, even if we inveigh
label: Paragraph

text: against the aestheticism of aesthetes one hundred times a day. Rejecting
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic demands (which is not the same as aesthetic speculation) would
label: Paragraph

text: be to saw off the branch on which one sits. As long as individual objects are
label: Paragraph

text: being deait with, the fulfillment of purpose may suffice to create a healthy
label: Paragraph

text: form. But if we accept the demands of a monumental architecture, that is,
label: Paragraph

text: of an architectural whole, the bringing together of forms— even genuinely
label: Paragraph

text: sound ones — does not suffice. The demand for unity is through and through
label: Paragraph

text: an elementary aesthetic or artistic demand, and to assume that all strictly
label: Paragraph

text: sachlich works “in themselves” would form a unity, even if they were devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped in a vacuum, is to draw a false conclusion. The task is not merely an
label: Paragraph

text: overview of new buildings but also an overview of their landscape or urban
label: Paragraph

text: environment.

label: Paragraph

text: House, human being, sun, and landscape form a complex of mutual relationships.

label: Paragraph

text: ships, so, for the sake of the overall idea, must a housing complex, as an overall
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: individual organisms converted to something impersonal. Only when they are all
label: Paragraph

text: conjoined do the parts attain the validity and meaning each intends. The types
label: Paragraph

text: that result from such architectural tasks are not a necessary evil of an anxious
label: Paragraph

text: economy; they are a necessity of life in terms of what a housing complex demands
label: Paragraph

text: and means and what the individual objects, considered within the same framework,

text: We should not abandon this demand because we are prejudiced —
label: Paragraph

text: rightly! — against previous romantic methods of doing it justice, The demand
label: Paragraph

text: itself remains as long as we do not abandon the full claim of design. A
label: Paragraph

text: bridge over a river is not just a utilitarian problem but also a town planning
label: Paragraph

text: problem, that is, the demand to insert its mass into the movement of the
label: Paragraph

text: bank, into the rhythm of the streets and squares, by means other than for-
label: Paragraph

text: mal nonsense and naturalistic mimicry is compietely an artistic-aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: one. One can deny these demands only by including under the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: utility the consideration of the optical and logical, of the perceptually cor-
label: Paragraph

text: rect, But then one has done nothing more than give aesthetic demands
label: Paragraph

text: another name. in fact, according to utilitarian dogmatists, there is a double
label: Paragraph

text: demand: the accord with sachlich-constructional demands and the accord
label: Title

text: with demands arising from the the nature of our organs of perception. And
label: Paragraph

text: it is precisely these that we call aesthetic demands in the pure, original
label: Paragraph

text: sense of the word (aiceé&vonot =| perceive). We do not doubt for a moment
label: Paragraph

text: that these demands, just as much as sachiich-constructional ones, belong
label: Paragraph

text: to the realm of human reason; these demands are not mystical and arbi-
label: Paragraph

text: trary nor are they in any way satisfied by that.

text: To care whether and if things relate to one another is under no circum-
label: Paragraph

text: stances a matter of utility. But if we abandon the demand for unity, we can
label: Paragraph

text: no longer speak well of design. The problem is not solved by the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: hitherto peaple have always tried to create unity in an emotional or roman-
label: Paragraph

text: tic fashion, using only the values and realities of the landscape, We have
label: Paragraph

text: to solve it on the basis of reason.
label: Paragraph

text: We find that German architecture is somewhat inclined to devote itself to
label: Paragraph

text: an extreme that changes fairly frequently and then gives way to the opposite
label: Paragraph

text: extreme — the consequence of inner uncertainty. It is all too rarely recog:
label: Paragraph

text: nized that the aim should be to stabilize the strong dynamic tensions that
label: Paragraph

text: living architecture must absorb in order not to become aesthetic, and this
label: Paragraph

text: certainly includes tensions of extreme revolutionary power and force, the
label: Paragraph

text: kind demanded by Selinski's essay.
label: Paragraph

text: It is erroneous to think that dynamism can only be expressed in the
label: Paragraph

text: elevation, in the animated “form” [Form]; instead, it is to a great degree a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of the floor plan. And it is just as erroneous to believe that structural
label: Paragraph

text: requirements are assured by a quadrature of the plan, which often enough
label: Paragraph

text: remains a drawing-board ornament. In contrast Mendelsohn says: “Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture establishes the conditions of its animated masses from its own laws:
label: Paragraph

text: the dynamic condition, movement of space (seen in outline as its linear ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ment), the rhythmic condition, the relationship of masses (seen in elevation
label: Paragraph

text: as tts surface projection), and the structural condition or balance of move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment (seen in plan and section as their structural elements).”
